Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 83 Filed: 10/17/11 Page 5 of 9 PageID #:823
 
Defendantsโ reply brief reaffirms the feebleness of their motion to dismiss, even making 
arguments that this Court effectively disposed of in its recent discovery order. See 10/12/11 
Opinion and Order [Doc. #77] at 6 (โProof of discriminatory intent is required for plaintiffs to 
prevail on their Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendment racial discrimination claimsโ and โhas also 
been found sufficient, though not necessary, to sustain a VRA claimโ); id. at 8 (โPlaintiffs allege 
many of [the totality of the circumstance] factors in their Complaint.โ); id. at 15-16 (โPlaintiffs 
raise profound questions about the legitimacy of the redistricting process and the viability of the 
2011 Map.โ).  
But  the  reply  brief  also  offers  two  new  arguments  that  Plaintiffs  have  not  had  the 
opportunity to address: First, as to Plaintiffsโ intentional discrimination claims (Counts I through 
III), Defendants now argue that the proportionality inquiry must focus on citizen voting age 
population, not voting age population. Second, as to Plaintiffsโ partisan gerrymander claims 
(Counts V and VI), Defendants invoke a recent decision from a federal district court in Texas 
that  dismissed  partisan  gerrymander  claims  because  the  plaintiffs  had  not  put  forward  an 
acceptable standard. In order to address these new argumentsโwhich are both meritlessโ
Plaintiffs hereby file this limited surreply. 
I.  Defendantsโ Argument Regarding Citizen Voting Age Population Is Meritless.  
Abandoning their opening briefโs ludicrous claim (at 6) that proportionality is a โdistrict-
specificโ concept, Defendants now argue (at 5-6) that the Complaint improperly focuses on the 
gross disparity between Illinoisโs 15.8% Latino voting age population and the 5.6% of majority-
Latino districts in Illinoisโs congressional redistricting plan. According to Defendants (at 6), the 
Complaint should instead have focused on โcitizen voting-age population,โ which Defendants 
now claim is โthe โproper benchmarkโ for measuring proportionality.โ  
Defendantsโ argument is absurdโand wrong. To begin with, it is remarkably untethered 
1 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 83 Filed: 10/17/11 Page 6 of 9 PageID #:824
 
from the standard that governs motions to dismiss. Defendants cannot plausibly claim that they 
lack  notice  of  Plaintiffsโ  claims  simply  because  the  Complaint  uses  voting  age  population 
(โVAPโ)  rather  than  citizen  voting  age  population  (โCVAPโ).  Regardless  of  the  โproper 
benchmarkโ for one of a number of relevant factors, the Complaint โgive[s] enough details about 
the subject-matter of the case to present a story that holds togetherโ (Swanson v. Citibank, N.A., 
614 F.3d 400, 404 (7th Cir. 2010)), which is all that it must do to survive a motion to dismiss.  
But  the  most  fundamental  problem  with  Defendantsโ  argument  is  that  VAPโnot 
CVAPโis the proper benchmark. โ[A]pportionment is based on Census returns,โ and all other 
โestimates about population . . . donโt matterโ in redistricting challenges. Gonzalez v. City of 
Aurora, Illinois, 535 F.3d 594, 597 (7th Cir. 2008). Prior to the 2010 Census, each decennial 
Census included questions on citizenship, and each Census report contained CVAP numbers. See 
U.S. Census Bureau, Decennial Census โ American FactFinder (noting that the 2000 Census 
included questions on citizenship)1; Gonzalez, 535 F.3d at 596 (listing CVAP figures from 2000 
Census). The 2010 Census eliminated questions on citizenship. See Kerry Pickett, 2010 Census 
Lacks Citizenship Question, WASH. TIMES, Jan. 11, 2010. As a result, the 2010 Census does not 
report CVAP numbers; it reports only VAP numbers, making VAP the appropriate benchmark. 
To be sure, one may try to estimate CVAP. And Defendantsโ expert appears to have done 
so by relying on โthe American Community Survey sample.โ See Expert Report of Allan J. 
Lichtman Re: Plaintiffsโ Allegations of Intentional Vote Dilution & Racial Predominance in 
Redistricting (Oct. 4, 2011) at 13. But, as the U.S. Census Bureau makes clear, โ[those numbers] 
are not the 2010 Census population counts.โ U.S. Census Bureau, American Community Survey, 
http://www.census.gov/acs/www/.  Any  estimates  drawn  from  that  sample  therefore  โdonโt 
                                                 
1  http://factfinder.census.gov/jsp/saff/SAFFInfo.jsp?_lang=en&_sse=on&_content=sp4_ 
decennial.html&_title=Decennial+Census. 
2 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 83 Filed: 10/17/11 Page 7 of 9 PageID #:825
 
matter.โ Gonzalez, 535 F.3d at 597.  
Because  the  2010  Census  does  not  contain  CVAP  numbers,  VAP  is  the  relevant 
benchmark. Thus, the disproportionality factor is satisfied.  
II.  Nothing  In  Perez  v.  Texas  Requires  This  Court  To  Dismiss  Plaintiffsโ  Partisan 
Gerrymandering Claims.  
Defendants never dispute that โa complaint need not contain legal theoriesโ (Aaron v. 
Mahl, 550 F.3d 659, 666 (7th Cir. 2008)) or โdo more than narrate a plausible claim for reliefโ 
(Morrison v. YTB Intโl, Inc., 649 F.3d 533, 538 (7th Cir. 2011)). But Defendants jettison (at 9-
11) this well-established body of law in seeking dismissal of Plaintiffsโ partisan gerrymander 
claims based on the reading that the district court in Perez v. Texas (W.D. Tex. Sept. 2, 2011) 
(Ex. A to Defsโ Reply Br.) recently gave to Justice Kennedyโs concurrence in Vieth v. Jubelirer, 
541 U.S. 267 (2004).  
The Perez court held that Justice Kennedyโs concurrence in Vieth required dismissal of 
partisan gerrymander claims where the plaintiffs did not articulate an acceptable standard for 
judging such claims. Speaking for only himself, Justice Kennedy took a similar position in Vieth. 
And the Perez court believed that aspect of Justice Kennedyโs concurrence was โcontrolling, 
because it is the โposition taken by those Members [of the Court] who concurred in the judgment 
on the narrowest grounds.โโ Slip op. at 21 (quoting Marks v. United States, 430 U.S. 188, 193 
(1977)).  
Perez misapplies the โMarks test,โ under which the so-called โnarrowestโ concurrence is 
treated as controlling. Subsequent to Marks, the Supreme Court has held that โ[w]e think it not 
useful to pursue the Marks inquiry to the utmost logical possibility when it has so obviously 
baffled and divided the lower courts that have considered it.โ Nichols v. United States, 511 U.S. 
738, 745-46 (1994). Moreover, โ[s]ince Marks, several members of the [Supreme] Court have 
3 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 83 Filed: 10/17/11 Page 8 of 9 PageID #:826
 
indicated that whenever a decision is fragmented such that no single opinion has the support of 
five Justices, lower courts should examine the plurality, concurring and dissenting opinions to 
extract the principles that a majority has embraced.โ United States v. Johnson, 467 F.3d 56, 65 
(1st Cir. 2006). 
Applying this correct standard to Vieth, controlling weight should not be given to Justice 
Kennedyโs view that complaints failing to articulate an acceptable standard should be dismissed. 
No other Justice in Vieth agreed that a complaint could be dismissed under Rule 12(b)(6) for 
failure to articulate a reliable legal standard. The plurality correctly noted that Justice Kennedyโs 
suggested disposition is โnot legally available,โ because โit is our job, not the plaintiffsโ, to 
explicate the standard that makes the facts alleged by the plaintiffs adequate or inadequate to 
state a claim.โ 541 U.S. at 301. The four dissenting Justices did not disagree with the plurality on 
that point, all voting against dismissal. Thus, what controls in Vieth is the eight-Justice majority 
that disagreed with Justice Kennedyโs rationale for dismissal.2  
The Vieth concurrence would upend federal pleading standards and offers no reason why 
a partisan gerrymander claim should be treated differently from any other claim under the Rule 
12(b)(6) analysis. Moreover, the Vieth concurrence has been superseded by Ashcroft v. Iqbal, in 
which Justice Kennedy wrote on behalf of a majority that โ[w]hen there are well-pleaded factual 
allegations, a court should assume their veracity and then determine whether they plausibly give 
rise to an entitlement to relief.โ 129 S. Ct. 1937, 1950 (2009). Under Iqbal, all that matters are a 
                                                 
2 LULAC v. Perry, 548 U.S. 399 (2006), also offers no support for Defendants. Both Perez (slip 
op. at 21) and Defendants (at 10) quote from Part II.B. of Justice Kennedyโs opinion in LULAC, 
butโonce moreโno other Justice joined Justice Kennedy on that point. Moreover, the passage 
in question simply stated that โa successful claim attempting to identify unconstitutional acts of 
partisan gerrymandering must . . . show a burden, as measured by a reliable standard, on the 
complainantsโ representational rights.โ Id. at 418. Plaintiffsโ Complaint satisfies that test. The 
Complaint alleges facts that โshow a burdenโ on Plaintiffsโ โrepresentational rightsโ under any 
โreliable standardโ that this Court might adopt. 
4 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 83 Filed: 10/17/11 Page 9 of 9 PageID #:827
 
complaintโs well-pleaded factual allegations; it is the courtโs role to determine whether those 
factual allegations โgive rise to an entitlement to relief.โ Id. 
Perez is also distinguishable. In Perez, the plaintiffs โwere given an opportunityโ to 
โidentif[y]โ a justiciable standard. Slip op. at 21. Here, Plaintiffs have not had that opportunity. 
The sole dispute at this point is whether the Complaint must โcontain legal theories.โ See Aaron, 
550  F.3d  at  666.  Should  this  Court  conclude  that  Plaintiffsโ  Complaint  must  articulate  a 
justiciable standard for partisan gerrymanders, then Plaintiffs should be given leave to file an 
amended pleading that offers such a standard. 
CONCLUSION 
The Court should deny Defendantsโ motion to dismiss. 
 
Dated: October 17, 2011        Respectfully submitted, 
 
/s/ Lori E. Lightfoot   
 
Tyrone C. Fahner 
John A. Janicik 
Lori E. Lightfoot 
Joshua D. Yount 
Dana S. Douglas 
Thomas V. Panoff 
MAYER BROWN LLP 
71 South Wacker Drive 
Chicago, Illinois 60606 
(312) 782-0600 
(312) 701-7711 โ fax  
 
Attorneys for Plaintiff 
 
5

documents.title: New Document

documents.document_source: PACER [Public Access to Court Electronic Records]
documents.title: Motion in Limine to Bar Plaintiffs' Fact Witnesses
documents.text:
Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 111 Filed: 11/10/11 Page 1 of 11 PageID #:2054
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF ILLINOIS, EASTERN DIVISION 
 
COMMITTEE FOR A FAIR AND BALANCED  )   
MAP, et al.,            ) 
              ) 
      Plaintiffs,      ) 
              )  Case No. 11-C-5065 
    v.           ) 
              )  Hon. John D. Tinder 
ILLINOIS STATE BOARD OF ELECTIONS,  )  Hon. Joan H. Lefkow 
et al.,              )  Hon. Robert L. Miller, Jr. 
            )  (3-judge court convened pursuant to  
      Defendants.      )  28 U.S.C. ยง 2284) 
 
MOTION IN LIMINE TO BAR PLAINTIFFSโ FACT WITNESSES 
 
Defendants, ILLINOIS STATE BOARD OF ELECTIONS, et al., by and through their 
counsel, Special Assistant Attorneys General Larry R. Rogers, Sr. and Devon C. Bruce, 
respectfully moves this Honorable Court for the entry of an Order, in limine, barring plaintiffsโ 
fact witnesses from testifying at the trial of this matter.  In support thereof, Defendants state: 
Introduction 
 
Plaintiffs have alleged in their complaint that the 2011 Illinois congressional map that 
passed both chambers of the Illinois legislature and was signed into law is unconstitutional in 
that (1) it violates Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act and (2) it is the result of political 
gerrymandering.  A number of courts addressing re-districting cases involving similar types of 
constitutional allegations have held that the decisions in these matters rise and fall largely based 
upon the partiesโ expert testimony. Barnett v. Daley, 1995 WL 59229 (N.D.Ill., Feb. 10, 1995); 
Illinois Legislative Redistricting Commission v. LaPaille, 786 F.Supp. 704 (N.D.Ill.1992).  This 
court has indicated as much in this case already: โI have already told (you) โ we have told you 
that we donโt think these witnesses are going to make a heck of a lot of difference.โ (Ex. A - 
Report of Proceedings dated 10/20/11 at p. 16.)   Despite this courtโs admonishment and defense 
1 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 111 Filed: 11/10/11 Page 2 of 11 PageID #:2055
counselโs requests to plaintiffsโ counsel to limit the number of fact witnesses or exchange 
deposition designations, plaintiffsโ counsel has insisted that they intend on calling no fewer than 
10 fact witnesses during this short hearing.  For the reasons set forth below, defendants move in 
limine to bar the testimony of 9 of the 10 plaintiff fact witnesses in their entirety or, in the 
alternative, at least bar these witnesses from testifying to certain topics, as described below.1 
Factual Background 
Congresswoman Judith Biggert  
Congresswoman Biggert never attended any Illinois re-districting committee hearings 
and never sent anyone on her behalf. (Ex. F - Biggert dep., p. 46)  She never submitted a letter, 
draft map or provided any input as to how she believed the map should be drawn before the 
adopted map was passed into law. (Ex. F - Biggert dep., p. 46)  Congresswoman Biggert never 
spoke to anyone who was involved in the drawing of the map. (Ex F - Biggert dep., p. 44)  She 
has no knowledge of the map-making process. (Ex. F - Biggert dep., p. 43)  She does not know 
anything about who drew the adopted map or what factors were considered by the map drawers 
in Springfield. (Ex. F - Biggert dep., p. 44)  She never made any effort to speak to the re-
districting committees while the legislature was going through the re-districting process. (Ex. F -
Biggert dep., p. 57)  Furthermore, she has no knowledge of the โdemographic makeupโ of the 
plaintiffsโ own map, including the Latino VAP in these districts proposed by plaintiffs. (Ex. F -
Biggert dep., p. 55-56)  She has never been told by anyone that the adopted map was 
intentionally drawn to discriminate against Latinos. (Ex. F - Biggert dep., p. 45-46) She has no 
knowledge of the demographic make-up of the map that was passed into law. (Ex. F - Biggert 
                                                           
1 Plaintiffs have indicated that they may call one other fact witness, Ed Marshall.  (See 
[Proposed] Pre-Hearing Order, filed November 7, 2011.)  Mr. Marshall is the subject of a 
separate Motion in Limine. 
2 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 111 Filed: 11/10/11 Page 3 of 11 PageID #:2056
dep., p. 46)  She has no knowledge of the demographic make-up of the map being offered by the 
plaintiffs. (Ex. F - Biggert dep., p. 55) 
Congressman Donald Manzullo  
Congressman Manzullo thinks he retained counsel before the map in Springfield was 
passed into law. (Ex. B - Manzullo dep., p. 34)  He never went to any Illinois re-districting 
committee hearings or submitted information to them.  Congressman Manzullo did not know if 
there were Republican members on the Illinois Re-Districting Committee. (Ex. B - Manzullo 
dep., pp. 31-32, 35-37, 49)  He does not know the identity or intent of those individuals who 
drew the adopted map. (Ex. B - Manzullo dep., pp. 16-17)  He believes that the intent was to give 
5-6 Republicans very difficult districts; however, he testified he has no first hand knowledge of 
this. (Ex. B - Manzullo dep., pp. 16-17)  No one ever told him that the intent of the drawers of 
the map was to discriminate against minorities. (Ex. B - Manzullo dep., pp. 30-31)  He is 
unaware of any minority groups that have objected to the new map. (Ex. B - Manzullo dep., p. 
51)2  Congressman Manzullo has no opinion as to whether the 17th Congressional District was 
drawn for partisan purposes: โI really do not have an opinion on that.โ (Ex. B - Manzullo dep., p. 
32)   Just like Congressman Shimkus, Congressman Manzullo testified that he was going to win 
regardless of whether he runs under the adopted map or the Republican map: โIโm going to win 
                                                           
2 Congressman Manzullo claimed that there were no minority groups in Rockford to voice 
objections because โI have always represented themโ. (Ex. B - Manzullo dep., pp. 51-52) 
Ironically, plaintiffsโ counsel chose to depose Rockford Mayor Lawrence J. Morrissey (over 
defendantsโ objection), who flatly contradicted Congressman Manzullo.  Mayor Morrissey 
identified a number of Latino and African-American community groups that are present in 
Rockford, including La Voz Latina, LULAC, Mexican American Chamber of Commerce and the 
NAACP. (Ex. G - Morrissey dep., pp. 54-55)  To the Mayorโs knowledge, none of these minority 
groups raised any objections to the adopted map.  (Ex. G - Morrissey dep., pp. 52,57)  In fact, a 
prominent local member of the minority community in Rockford, Representative Chuck 
Jefferson, publicly voted to support the adopted map. (Ex. G - Morrissey dep., pp. 52-53)  Mayor 
Morrissey went on to explain the benefits of having Rockford divided into two Congressional 
districts.  (Ex. G - Morrissey dep., pp. 47-49) 
3 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 111 Filed: 11/10/11 Page 4 of 11 PageID #:2057
in either district because Iโve represented most of that area for the past 18 years.โ (Ex. B -
Manzullo dep., p. 42) 
Congressman Peter Roskam 
Congressman Roskam does not know the names of the individuals who drew the map. 
(Ex. D - Roskam dep., p. 23)  Congressman Roskam has no knowledge of the intent of the 
individuals who created the adopted map. (Ex. D - Roskam dep., p. 24)  He had no involvement 
in the Illinois re-districting process. (Ex. D - Roskam dep., pp. 36-39)  He neither attended any of 
the re-districting committee meetings nor sent anyone of his behalf. (Ex. D - Roskam dep., p. 36-
37) He never attempted to provide the re-districting committee with any alternative maps, 
although nothing precluded him from doing so. (Ex. D - Roskam dep., p. 37)  No one has told 
him that the intent in drawing the map that was passed into law was to discriminate against 
minorities. (Ex. D - Roskam dep., p. 24)  He cannot say that the adopted map is less 
advantageous for him than the map the plaintiffs themselves are proposing. (Ex. D - Roskam 
dep., p. 44)  
Congressman John Shimkus 
Congressman Shimkus had retained counsel in early Spring or mid-April.  Congressman 
Shimkus does not know who drew the adopted map that was passed into law. (Ex. E - Shimkus 
dep., pp. 51-54)  He never spoke to anyone involved in Springfield about the intent of the map 
drawing.  (Ex. E - Shimkus dep., p. 97)  He attended none of the Illinois re-districting committee 
hearings himself; nor did he have anyone attend these meeting on his behalf; nor did he provide 
any maps or have his counsel do so. (Ex. E - Shimkus dep., pp. 113-18, 122, 124-25)  He has no 
knowledge that the adopted map was intended by the drafters to discriminate against Latinos. 
(Ex. E - Shimkus dep., pp. 99-102)  In contradiction to the plaintiffsโ complaint, Congressman 
4 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 111 Filed: 11/10/11 Page 5 of 11 PageID #:2058
Shimkus said prior to the adoption of the map that he was willing to accept a map with only one 
Latino majority district. (Ex. H - Lipinski dep., pp. 34-36)  Despite plaintiffsโ claim of 
disadvantage under the new map, Congressman Shimkus has no knowledge about the percentage 
of Democrats or Republicans in any Congressional district in Southern Illinois under the map 
that has passed into law. (Ex. E - Shimkus dep., p. 21) Congressman Shimkus summarized his 
knowledge of the map up by simply stating, โall the information I have on the map is based 
upon privileged communication with my attorneys.โ (Ex. E - Shimkus dep., pp. 26-27)  Upon 
further questioning about percentages of Democratic versus Republican voters in the newly 
adopted 15th District, Congressman Shimkus continued to maintain that all of the information he 
had was based on attorney-client privilege. (Ex. E - Shimkus dep., pp. 35-37) 
Argument 
I.  The four Congressional plaintiffs should be barred from offering testimony 
as they possess no knowledge as to the allegations in the plaintiffsโ amended 
complaint 
 
  A.  The Congressional plaintiffs should be barred from testifying that 
they were deprived of participation in the re-districting process 
 
 Both the original and amended complaints are replete with allegations of a โback room 
map making processโ and the plaintiffs themselves testified that they were โshut outโ of the 
process. (Ex. B - Manzullo dep., p. 31)  The facts obtained in discovery, however, reveal that the 
plaintiffs retained the law firm of Mayer Brown in this matter as early as December 2010 or 
January 2011, long before the re-districting process had even begun.  (Ex. C - Schock dep., p. 
17.)  None of the Congressional plaintiffs attended any of the numerous Illinois Re-Districting 
Committee hearings held throughout the State.  None of the plaintiffs or their counsel submitted 
any proposed ideas, thoughts or maps to the Re-Districting Committee as to how they believed 
the map should have been drawn.  It is undisputed that nothing prevented the plaintiffs from 
5 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 111 Filed: 11/10/11 Page 6 of 11 PageID #:2059
doing so. (Ex. D - Roskam dep., p. 37)  In short, neither the plaintiffs, nor their counsel, made 
any attempt to participate in the re-districting process and thus should be barred on foundational 
grounds from offering testimony or opinions that they were โshut outโ of the process or that it 
would not have made a difference if they had chosen to do so (which they did not).  Put simply, 
the plaintiffs should not be allowed to testify that they were deprived of participating in the re-
districting process when they never made any attempt to do so. 
  B.  The Congressional plaintiffs should be barred from testifying as to 
how or why the adopted map was created 
 
As became clear in discovery, the Congressional plaintiffs do not know who drew the 
map at issue.  The Congressional plaintiffs do not know what factors the drafters relied upon in 
drawing the map.  None of the Congressional plaintiffs have any knowledge that the map was 
drawn to intentionally discriminate against the Latinos, which goes to the heart of the alleged 
violations of Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act.  Lastly, the Congressional plaintiffs either 
claimed not to have analyzed the demographics of the newly adopted map in order to determine 
with any detail the political ramifications of the map or they refused to answer questions about 
the political composition of the map. (Ex. D - Roskam dep., p. 14; Ex. E - Shimkus dep., pp. 21, 
26-27)  The Congressional plaintiffs clearly are unhappy with the adopted map and would like to 
โsay their peaceโ.  As the court already has pointed out, however, in granting defendantsโ motion 
to quash the deposition subpoena for Congressman Jesse Jackson, Jr., โevery Congressman has a 
political opinion about it.โ (Ex. A - Report of Proceedings dated 10/20/11 at p. 12)  Nevertheless, 
allowing the Congressional plaintiffs to make broad, conclusory statements about why they 
believe the map was drawn the way it was is rank speculation when they lack knowledge about 
who drew the map, what factors the drafters relied upon or the details of the political 
6 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 111 Filed: 11/10/11 Page 7 of 11 PageID #:2060
ramifications of the map.  See, e.g., Alston v. King, 231 F. 3d 383, 387 (7th Cir. 2000) (affirming 
the exclusion of evidence that both lacked foundation and was speculative). 
  C.  The Congressional plaintiffs should be barred from testifying about 
alleged out of court statements made by non-parties  
 
Several of the Congressional plaintiffs testified in their depositions to various 
conversations they claim they had with non-party individuals about the map.  These individuals 
who the Congressional plaintiffs claim to have spoken to include Illinois Senate President John 
Cullerton, Illinois House Speaker Michael Madigan, Congressman Jerry Costello, former 
Congressman William Lipinski, Congressman Jesse Jackson Jr., State Senator Bill Haine and 
State Representative Dan Beiser.  All of these alleged statements are plain hearsay and as such 
the Congressional plaintiffs should not be allowed to testify to these alleged conversations with 
non-parties. See, e.g., U.S. v. Lane, 323 F.3d 568, 584 (7th Cir. 2003) (affirming exclusion of 
conversation as inadmissible hearsay).  Specifically, defendants expect the plaintiffs to attempt to 
elicit testimony from Congressman Shimkus and Congressman Costello regarding a compromise 
that they attempted to reach regarding the congressional boundaries of a map.  Not only are 
Congressman Costelloโs out of court statements hearsay, the whole topic area is irrelevant.  A 
compromise was not reached between these two Congressmen and any map that they discussed 
was not adopted into law and has no bearing on the issues in this case. 
  D.  The Congressional plaintiffs should be barred from testifying 
regarding the plaintiffsโ โRepublicanโ map 
 
As part of the plaintiffsโ case, the plaintiffs have proffered a self-styled โFair and 
Balanced Mapโ candidly referred to by plaintiff Congressman Manzullo as the โRepublican 
Mapโ. (Ex. B - Manzullo dep., pp. 40, 41)   During the depositions of each of the Congressional 
plaintiffs, they denied any substantive knowledge about this โRepublicanโ Map.  The 
7 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 111 Filed: 11/10/11 Page 8 of 11 PageID #:2061
Congressional plaintiffs either did not know or were precluded by their counsel from answering 
any questions about the partisan make-up of the โRepublicanโ map or the percentage of Latino 
VAP in a particular district or any other details about the partisan make-up of the plaintiffsโ 
proffered map. (Ex. D - Roskam dep., pp. 44-45; Ex. C - Schock dep., pp. 48-49; Ex. E - 
Shimkus dep., pp. 135-36)  As such, the plaintiffs should be precluded from offering any such 
details at the hearing and leave such testimony, if any, to the experts. 
  E.  The Congressional plaintiffs should be barred from offering testimony 
or opinions about the political ramifications of the adopted map 
 
Surprisingly, several of the Congressional plaintiffs testified to their likelihood of 
prevailing under the adopted map, which refutes the plaintiffsโ gerrymandering contention 
entirely.  For example, Congressman Shimkus testified that โit would be very difficult for a 
district to be drawn in Southwestern Illinois that I cannot win inโ. (Ex. E - Shimkus dep., p. 64)  
Congressman Schock testified that his new district is advantageous for a Republican. (Ex. C-
Schock dep., pp. 44-45)  Furthermore, none of the Congressional plaintiffs testified to any 
detailed information on the partisan composition of the newly adopted map.  Congressman 
Shimkus testified he had no knowledge of the percentage of Republican versus Democratic 
voters in the newly drawn Congressional map. (Ex. E - Shimkus dep., pp. 26-27)  Furthermore, 
when pressed for details about the analysis of the partisan make-up of the adopted map, the 
Congressional plaintiffs did not have any information (or were instructed by counsel not to 
answer) regarding any partisan percentages. (See Ex. E - Shimkus dep., pp. 26-27, 35-37)  As 
such, the Congressional plaintiffs should be precluded from testifying regarding any details of 
the partisan composition of the adopted map at the hearing of this matter. 
 
 
8 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 111 Filed: 11/10/11 Page 9 of 11 PageID #:2062
 
II.  The citizen plaintiff fact witnesses should be barred from offering any 
opinion testimony as they lack the foundation and expertise  
 
For all of the reasons as to why the Congressional plaintiffs should be barred from 
testifying, the citizen plaintiff fact witnesses should be barred from offering any opinion 
testimony as well.  The citizen plaintiffs who have been identified as witnesses for trial are Ralph 
Rangel, Lou Sandoval, Luis Sanabria, and Michelle Caballero.  These plaintiff fact witnesses 
have as little knowledge about the issues raised in the amended complaint as do the 
Congressional plaintiffs.  None of the citizen witnesses took part in or have any knowledge about 
how the adopted map was created. (Ex. I - Sanabria dep., pp. 12-15; Ex. J - Caballero dep., pp. 
19, 20, 21; Ex. K - Rangel dep., p. 41-46)  Although several of the citizen witnesses have their 
own personal opinions about the adopted Fourth Congressional District, they are simply non-
expert opinions.  None of the citizen witnesses reviewed, discussed or said that they relied upon 
any demographic data.   
For example, Mr. Sanabriaโs testimony simply reiterates the allegations in plaintiffsโ 
amended complaint that the adopted map, โpacks Hispanic voters into District #4โ and 
diminishes Hispanic influence in Districts #3 and #5. (Ex. I - Sanabria dep., pp. 11-12, 23-24) 
These conclusory opinions lack any foundation.  Mr. Sanabria has not reviewed or relied upon 
any data to make these statements.   
Similarly, Lou Sandovalโs testimony re-stated the allegations in the amended complaint, 
but without foundation.  While Mr. Sandoval volunteered that his statements are supported by 
census data and a New York Times article, he neither offered specifics as to his opinions nor 
detailed any educational and professional background in the areas of demography, political 
science, statistics, quantitative methodologies, electoral analysis, or election law that would 
9 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 111 Filed: 11/10/11 Page 10 of 11 PageID #:2063
make him qualified to render those opinions. (Ex. L - Sandoval dep., p. 6-8; 75-82)  After 
discussing the map with plaintiffsโ lawyers, Ms. Caballero stated that she believes that the map 
unfairly segregates the 4th and 5th Districts into one Hispanic District. (Ex. J - Caballero dep., pp. 
25-28)  However, she likewise has no statistical or other expertise to render that opinion.  Lastly, 
without any analysis whatsoever, Mr. Rangel testified that he is not really aware of the adopted 
map, but that it would create a potential of Spanish block other than District #4. (Ex. K - Rangel 
dep., pp. 30-31, 36-37) 
Conclusion 
For the reasons set forth above, defendants respectfully request that the four 
Congressional plaintiffs be barred from testifying at the hearing of this matter in their entirety or, 
in the alternative, request that the Congressional plaintiffs be barred from testifying regarding the 
following topics: 
  A.  Conclusions/opinions that they were โshut outโ of the re-map process or 
that it would not have made a difference if they participated in the process; 
 
  B.  The map drawersโ intent or factors that the drawers relied upon in drawing 
the adopted map;   
 
  C.  How or why the Congressional boundaries on the adopted map were 
drawn; 
 
  D.  That the intention of the map drawers was to intentionally discriminate 
against Latinos; 
 
  E.  Any details or statistical data about the plaintiffsโ proffered map, also 
referred to as the โRepublican Mapโ; 
 
  F.  Any details or statistical data regarding the partisan breakdown of the 
adopted map; 
 
    G.  Any alleged out of court statements made by non-parties, including but not 
limited to: 
 
      Illinois Senate President John Cullerton 
10 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 111 Filed: 11/10/11 Page 11 of 11 PageID #:2064
      Illinois House Speaker Michael Madigan 
      Congressman Jerry Costello 
      Former Congressman William Lipinski 
      Congressman Jesse Jackson Jr.  
 
  H.  Any draft maps exchanged between Congressman Shimkus and 
Congressman Costello. 
 
  Plaintiff further moves this court to bar any opinion testimony from the citizen plaintiff 
fact witnesses due to lack of foundation and relevance including, but not limited to, any 
testimony that: 
  A.  the adopted map โpacksโ the Fourth Congressional District with Latinos 
  B.  that the Hispanic vote in the 3rd and 5th Districts are diminished. 
 
            Respectfully submitted,     
           
 
    /s/   Devon C. Bruce                    
    Counsel for Defendants 
 
 
  Larry R. Rogers, Sr.

)   Judge Robert L. Miller

WILLIAM M. MCGUFFRAGE, JESSE R.  )    to 28 U.S.C. ยง 2284)

PLAINTIFFSโ MOTION TO COMPEL ENFORCEMENT 
OF THIRD PARTY SUBPOENA
Pursuant to FED. R. CIV. PROC. 37(a)(3)(B)(i) and 45(c)(2)(B)(i), Plaintiffs respectfully 
move this Court to compel the enforcement of the subpoena duces tecum (โSubpoenaโ) duly 
served on Congressman Jerry Costello on September 22, 2011.  Plaintiffs ask the Court to 
compel Congressman Costello to produce documents responsive to the subpoena, and to provide 
testimony regarding  the  Congressmanโs  discussions  with  the  Democratic  Congressional 
Campaign  Committee  (โDCCCโ)  and  other  current  and  former  Congressman  regarding  the 
Illinois redistricting process.  In support of this motion, Plaintiffs state:
1

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 90 Filed: 10/24/11 Page 2 of 8 PageID #:851
INTRODUCTION
1. Plaintiffs served the Subpoena on Congressman Jerry Costello on September 22, 
2011.  Ex. A.  The Subpoena sought documents and testimonyrelated to Congressman Costelloโs 
involvement in the Illinois redistricting process, as well as his conversations with other members 
of the Illinois congressional delegation about the redistricting process.  
2.  In a letter dated October 11, 2011, counsel for Congressman Costello, Robert 
Shannon, indicated two categories of objections to the subpoena.  Ex. B at 1.  First, counsel 
objected that to the extent the subpoena related to information โexchanged among, or reflecting 
communications among, Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) members 
(including Members of Congress and their aides), agents, consultants and/or attorneys relating to 
Illinois congressional redistricting,โ the Congressman was adopting objections made by the 
DCCC in connection with a subpoena and motion to compel served on the DCCC by Plaintiffs. 
Id.  The DCCC has objected to production of documents on the ground of First Amendment 
privilege.  Plaintiffsโ motion to compel is still pending in the District of the District of Columbia.  
On Friday, October 21, 2011, the court ordered the DCCC to produce certain categories of 
documents, but has yet to rule on the DCCCโs invocation of the First Amendment privilege.  
Ex.C.
3. The second set of objections related to โmaterial reflecting information exchanged 
among, or reflecting communications among, Congressman Costello and his aides regarding 
Illinois congressional redistricting.โ  Ex. B at 1.  With respect to these materials, Congressman 
Costello again adopted the objections raised by the DCCC, and further objected on the ground 
that the material was protected by the โlegislative immunityand deliberative process privileges.โ  
Id. 
2

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 90 Filed: 10/24/11 Page 3 of 8 PageID #:852
4.  Congressman Costello sat for his deposition on October 19, 2011.  Ex. D (โDep.โ) 
At the deposition, Mr. Shannon, the Congressmanโs counsel, reiterated the above objections.  
Dep. at 5-7.    Then, at least six times, Congressman Costello refused, on the advice of counsel, 
to answer questions regarding the substance of his conversations with other current Democratic 
members of the Illinois congressional delegation regarding the redistricting process in Illinois. 
SeeDep. at 29 (Lipinski), 30 (Schakowsky, Jackson, Rush), 31 (Rush, Guttierez, Davis).  
6.  In  addition  to  Congressman  Costelloโs  refusal  to  answer  Plaintiffsโ  questions 
regarding  conversations  about  Illinois  redistricting  with  current  members  of  Congress, 
Congressman  Costello  took  inconsistent  position  regarding  his  conversations  with  former
Democratic Congressman William Lipinski,1  asserting privilege at one point, Dep. at 44-46, but 
later discussing the substanceof a conversation. Dep. at 49.
7. Also at the deposition, counsel for Congressman Costello acknowledged that the 
Congressman possessed documents responsive to the subpoena.  Dep. at 10.  Those documents 
were similarly withheld from production pursuant to the same privilege invocation. See Ex. B at 
1.
8.   None  of  Congressman  Costelloโs  assertions of  privilege  was  justified.    The 
Congressman has no grounds for claiming the protection of the First Amendment, nor does any 
of the information sought by Plaintiffs come within the scope of any privilege or immunity he 
enjoys  as  a  member  of  Congress.    Accordingly,  Plaintiffs  request  that  the  Court  direct 
Congressman Costello to produce all documents responsive to the subpoena and to answer the 
questions posed to him or provide testimonyon the subject matter raised byPlaintiffsโ counsel at 
his depositionas to which he invoked privilege.
   
1 Congressman Costello could not confirm whether former Congressman Lipinski is a member of the DCCC.  
The DCCC website states that membership is composed of currentmembers of Congress.
3

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 90 Filed: 10/24/11 Page 4 of 8 PageID #:853
ARGUMENT
A.  Congressman Costello Has No First Amendment Privilege To Assert Here.
The First Amendment privilege against compliance with discovery requests exists to 
protect the โvital relationship between freedom to associate and privacy in oneโs associations.โ  
NAACP v. Alabama, 357 U.S. 449, 462 (1958) (emphasis added).  Congressman Costelloโs 
assertion of a First Amendment privilege fails for several reasons.  
First, as Plaintiffs demonstrated in their Reply Brief in Support of their Motion to 
Compel against the DCCC, Ex. E, the information Plaintiffs seek is not the kind of information 
the First Amendment protects.  Case after case makes clear that the root of the First Amendment 
privilege against discovery is a concern with exposing information such as an organizationโs 
membership lists, the names of donors, the names of potential participants in an organizationโs 
activities and the like.  See, e.g., Intโl Action Center v. U.S., 207 F.R.D. 1, 2 (D.D.C. 2002) 
(information  about  participants  or  potential  participants  at  protest  is  โexactly  the  kind  of 
information the First Amendment is designed to protectโ); Britt v. Superior Court, 20 Cal. 3d 
844, 852 (Cal. 1978) (โIn compelling the wholesale disclosure of private association affiliations 
and activities, the challenged discovery order works an unconstitutional infringement of First 
Amendment rights.โ); Wilkinson v. F.B.I, 111 F.R.D. 432, 436 (C.D. Cal. 1986) (โA review of 
the cases applying the privilege reveals that in each case the discovery that was subject to 
enhanced First Amendment scrutiny was a specific request for a groupโs membership list or list 
of financial contributors.โ).  
Plaintiffs have not sought and do not want any information related to membership or 
support of the DCCC or any other group to which Congressman Costello might belong.  Nor, 
have Plaintiffs sought information regarding the internal strategies of the DCCC related to 
upcoming congressional elections in Illinois or elsewhere.  See Perry v. Schwarzenegger, 591
4

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 90 Filed: 10/24/11 Page 5 of 8 PageID #:854
F.3d  1147,  1162  (9th  Cir.  2010)  (internal  strategy documents  may be  protected).      What  
Plaintiffs have asked for is a narrow category of information and testimony related only to 
Congressman Costelloโs involvement in the redistricting process in Illinois.  That process was 
not part of the internal workings of the DCCC.  The Congressman, the DCCC, and other 
members of the Illinois Democratic congressional delegation all chose to inject themselves into 
that process, and cannot now claim privilege over communications relating to their involvement 
in that process. See, e.g., Ex. F (Dkt. 77, Opinion and Order holding that legislative privilege did 
not apply to Illinois legislatorsโ conversations with the DCCC).  It is simply not credible for 
Congressman Costello(or anyone else) to now argue that he has a privacyinterest to protect with 
regard to his particular involvement.  There can be no expectation of privacy when one injects 
himself into such aprocess.
Second, Congressman Costelloโs interest in redistricting is wholly related to his status as 
an  officeholder  under  the  very map  at  issue.  For  this  very reason,  any claim  that  his 
communications about such a mapโwith anyoneโimpinge upon his right to associate privately
is nonsense.  The First Amendment exists because โpublic identification of individuals who 
never intended their participation in First Amendment activity to thrust them into the harsh glare 
of the limelightโ can work to โchill future political dissent and discourage participation in other 
protest activity.โ  Intโl Action Center, 207 F.R.D. at 3-4.  But as a public official whose political 
associations are long established and well known, the Congressman cannot credibly claim that 
disclosure of his conversations with other office holders, whose associations are also well-
known, will result in any chilling effect at all.  Indeed, many of the conversations about which 
Plaintiffs seek testimony occurred on the floor of the United States House of Representatives.  
See Dep. at 28.   It is simply absurd to suggest that Congressman Costello or his fellow members 
5

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 90 Filed: 10/24/11 Page 6 of 8 PageID #:855
of Congress need or are entitled to the First Amendmentโs protection from the limelight.  This is 
particularly true where, as is the case here, the communications were about a public legislative 
process.  
Third, Congressman Costello has already waived any particular privileges that might 
have attached by discussing the involvement of himself and other DCCC members, employees, 
and  agents  in  the  Illinois  Congressional  redistricting  process  with  several  different  people, 
including Plaintiffs in this very lawsuit.  Although Congressman Costello has asserted privilege 
over, for example, document  โreflecting  communications  among, Democratic Congressional 
Campaign Committee (DCCC) members (including Members of Congress and their aides),โ Ex. 
B at 1, he nonetheless discussed his conversations with the DCCC, Senator Dick Durbin, and 
Congresswoman Jan Schakowsky about the DCCCโs involvement in the redistricting process
with Republican Congressman John Shimkus.  Ex. G (Deposition of John Shimkus), at 53.  And, 
as noted above, while Congressman Costello asserted privilege as to conversations with other 
Democratic  members of  the  Illinois  delegation (i.e.  members  of  the  DCCC),  he  also  told 
Congressman Shimkus that, based on those conversations, Costello believed that a bipartisan 
redistricting compromise might be possible.  Dep. at 33.  Furthermore, Congressman Costello 
discussed  the  same  matters,  based  on  the  same  conversations,  with  legislative  leaders  in 
Springfield, such as Senate President John Cullerton and House Speaker Mike Madigan.2  After 
disclosing his supposedly privileged conversations with so many different people, Congressman 
Costello cannot now seriously claim that his associational privacy will be adversely affected by 
giving testimony about the same matters that he has already discussed so openly with people 
   
2 This Court already has ruled that such conversations as well as any others between the Illinois General 
Assembly or its members or staff and third parties, including representatives of the DCCC, are not protected by any 
privilege held by member of the Illinois General Assembly, and are thus discoverable in this litigation. Ex. F(Dkt. 
77).
6

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 90 Filed: 10/24/11 Page 7 of 8 PageID #:856
outside the DCCC. 
B.  Congressman Costello Can Assert No Claim Of Legislative Immunity Or
Deliberative Process Privilege
Congressman Costelloโs assertions of legislative immunity and/or deliberative process 
privilege are likewise without merit.  Congressman Costello is a member of the United States 
House  of  Representatives.    But  the  drawing  of the  Illinois  Congressional  Map  is  the 
responsibility of  the  Illinois  General  Assembly,  not  the  U.S.  House.    In  other  words,  the 
Congressman had no official involvement in the remapping process whatsoever.  He therefore 
cannot invoke privileges that exist to protect members of Congress in the conduct of their official 
duties.  See Gravel v. United States, 408 U.S. 606, 625 (1972) (protection of the Speech and 
Debate  Clause  only  reaches  matters  that  are  an  โintegral  part  of  the  deliberative  and 
communicative processes by which Members participate in committee and House proceedings 
with respect to the consideration and passage or rejection of proposed legislation or with respect 
to other matters which the Constitution places within the jurisdiction of either Houseโ).  Because 
none of the information sought in this case relates to the official duties or responsibilities of 
Congressman Costelloโs office, neither the federal legislative immunity nor the deliberative 
process privilegehas any application here. 
CONCLUSION
WHEREFORE,  for  the  foregoing  reasons,  the  Court  should  order  Respondent 
Congressman Costello to produce documents responsive to the subpoena and provide testimony 
regarding his conversations with the DCCC and other current and former members of Congress 
related to the Illinois redistricting process.
7

Dear Ms. Lightfoot:  
Pursuant  to  our  discussion  yesterday  and  Rule  45(c)(2)(B),  the  following  serves  as 
objections to the subpoena request directed at Congressman Costello (โRespondentโ): 
Objections Applicable to Requests 1-9 
Each Request for Production relates to โthe Proposed Congressional Plan.โ  Therefore, as 
to  each  request,  Respondent  objects  to  documents  and/or  material  exchanged  among,  or 
reflecting communications among, Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) 
members (including Members of Congress and their aides), agents, consultants and/or attorneys 
relating  to  Illinois  congressional  redistricting.    In  support  of  these  objections,  Respondent 
specifically  adopts  those  objections  and  arguments  made  by  the  DCCC  in  both  its 
correspondence to you of August 26, 2011 and in its response to plaintiffโs motion to compel the 
DCCC. 
Respondent also objects to any documents or material reflecting information exchanged 
among, or reflecting communications among, Congressman Costello and his aides regarding 
Illinois congressional redistricting.  In support of said objection, Respondent again adopts those 
objections raised by the DCCC and states that such information is protected by the legislative 
immunity and deliberative process privileges. 
  Subject to and without waiver, we discussed that I have documents that fall into the 
above categories, but at this time you do not require a privilege log.  We understand that you 
may choose to insist upon a log at a later date.  
 
  Please feel free to call me with any questions.

INTRODUCTION
Plaintiffs have alleged in the underlying case that the Springfield, Illinois Democratic
legislature, as directed by the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (โDCCCโ),
violated the United States Constitution and the Voting Rights Act when it drew Illinoisโ
congressional districts following the 2010 census. As a part of discovery, Plaintiffs subpoenaed
the DCCC and requested a limited set of documents related to the DCCCโs involvement in the
Illinois redistricting process. Ever since it was served with Plaintiffsโ subpoena (โSubpoenaโ),
however, the DCCC has utterly rejected its obligations pursuant to the Federal Rules of Civil
Procedure. Both its blanket objections and bad faith approach to the meet and confer process
demonstrate the DCCCโs total disregard for the duly issued Subpoena. Likewise, the DCCCโs
September 22, 2011 Opposition to Plaintiffsโ Motion to Compel (โOppositionโ) relies upon
blatant mischaracterizations of Plaintiffsโ undeniably narrow document requests, the DCCCโs
own organization and membership, and inapposite case law in an effort to thwart standard
discovery of relevant documents that are central to Plaintiffsโ claims now pending in the
NorthernDistrictofIllinois.
The DCCCโs assertion that it has no obligation to comply with the Subpoena in light of
the pending motion to dismiss is meritless given that, by the directive of the presiding judge in
the underlying matter, the parties to the underlying action are proceeding with their fact and
expert discovery. In fact, Judge Lefkowโs August 11, 2011 order (โOrderโ) setting a briefing
scheduleand grantingexpedited discoveryspecificallyaccounted forthe fact thattheDefendants
might file a motion to dismiss (Order ยถ 1). Nevertheless, the Order requires that discovery
continue, setting expert discovery deadlines of September 14 and September 28 (id. ยถ 2.3), and

ARGUMENT
I. There Is Nothing โPrematureโ About Plaintiffsโ Discovery Requests Or Motion To
CompelComplianceTherewith.
As explained in Plaintiffsโ September 8, 2011 Motion To Compel Democratic
Congressional Campaign Committee To Comply With Subpoena Seeking Third Party Discovery
(โMotion to Compelโ), โRule 45 subpoenas are โdiscoveryโ under Rules 16 and 26 of the Federal
Rules of Civil Procedure, and are subject to the same deadlines as other forms of discovery.โ
Dag Enters., Inc. v. Exxon Mobil Corp., 226 F.R.D. 95, 104 (D.D.C. 2005). Moreover, โ[a]
scheduling order is not a frivolous piece of paper, idly entered, which can be cavalierly
disregarded bycounselwithoutperil. Indeed,disregardoftheorderwould underminethecourtโs
abilityto control its docket, disrupt the agreed-upon course of litigation, and reward the indolent
andthecavalier.โ Id. (internalcitationsandbracketsomitted).
According to the Order entered by Judge Lefkow in the underlying action as well as her
standing order (Mot. Ex. K), discovery proceeds unabated even during the pendency of the
briefing of the motion to dismiss. Specifically, the Order sets expert discovery deadlines of
September 14 and September 28 (Order ยถ 2.3), and mandates that โ[d]iscovery shall be
completed by October 19, 2011.โ Id. ยถ 2.8. As set forth in the Motion to Compel, expedited
discovery is necessary because of the looming deadlines related to the 2012 election season, for
which the Plan was created. Mot. ยถ 5. Thus, the DCCC has absolutely no right to defy that
OrderandignoretheSubpoena,a courtorder,simplybecausethemotiontodismissispending.
The DCCC cannot unilaterally decide what schedule suits it, particularly in the face of a
valid Subpoena and an established expedited briefingand discoveryschedule agreed upon bythe
parties and ordered by a United States District Judge. In addition, it is not up to the DCCC to
decide whether discovery should be stayed pending a decision on the motion to dismiss the

underlying action. That determination is solely for the court to make, and the DCCC has made

Because the DCCC and/or its agents were instrumental in the creation of the Plan, the

Case: C1a:1s1e- c1v:1-015-m06c5-0 D0o5c1u4m-DeAnRt #  :  D9o0c-1u mFielendt :1 130  / 2 F4i/l1e1d  P0a9g/2e9 4/191 o  f  P1a4g8e P 8a goef I2D4 #:906
creation of the Plan. Indeed, the DCCC has admitted as much. Opp. at 5. Plaintiffs must be
allowedtodiscoverthesematerials.
Further, the DCCCโs argument that evidence of discriminatory effect will come from
experts is a canard. Rule 26(b)(1) permits discovery โregarding any nonprivileged matter that is
relevant to any partyโs claim or defense.โ FED. R. CIV. P. 26(b)(1). See also Heat & Control,
Inc. v. Hester Indus., Inc., 785 F.2d 1017, 1023 (Fed. Cir. 1986) (noting that Rule 45 must be
read in light of Rule 26(b)). For that matter, regardless of the DCCCโs efforts to evaluate
Plaintiffsโ claims and strategies in the underlying action, the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure
impose no requirement that the material sought be relevant to every element of a claim.
Furthermore, while discriminatory effect is a factor in Plaintiffsโ partisan gerrymander claim
under Davis v. Bandemer, 479 U.S. 109 (1986), it is discriminatory intent that is an integral
element of each of Plaintiffsโ claims. See Garza v. County of Los Angeles, 918 F.2d 763, 766
(9th Cir. 1990) (the Voting Rights Act can be violated by either intentional discrimination or
discriminatory effect); Miller v. Johnson, 515 U.S. 900, 916 (1995) (plaintiff's burden in a racial
gerrymander claim under the Equal Protection Clause is to show that โthat race was the
predominant factor motivating the legislature's decision to place a significant number of voters
within or without a particular districtโ); Davis, 478 U.S. at 127 (plurality) (to succeed on an
equal protection claim, a plaintiff must plead and ultimately prove intentional discrimination
against an identifiable group and an actual discriminatory effect on that group). The documents
sought by Plaintiffsโ Subpoena are highly relevant to Plaintiffsโ claims related to discriminatory
intent in the creation of the Plan, and that is sufficient to make the information on the DCCCโs
roleindraftingthePlan discoverable.

III. The First Amendment Does Not Preclude Production Of Documents Pursuant To
TheSubpoena.
First Amendment interests are not implicated by Plaintiffsโ Subpoena. The Subpoena
requests a limited range of documents related to the DCCCโs involvement in the process (which
is now long over) that resulted in the Illinois congressional district map that was signed into law
in late June. It does not seek information about private citizens who affiliate with the DCCC,
membership lists, or donor listsโthe types of materials that typically raise First Amendment
concerns. Nor does it seek to pry into the DCCCโs campaign strategies for the upcoming
elections. The Illinois redistricting process is long over, and it is untenable to maintain that
documents related to that process have anything to do with the strategy for the upcoming 2012
elections. Moreover, the DCCCโs members, all members of Congress, are well-known public
officeholders,4 distinguishing the DCCC from other groups who have availed themselves of the
FirstAmendmentโs protectionofprivateassociationalactivity.
4 Asdiscussedfurtherbelow,theDCCC callsitselfโtheofficialcampaignarmofthe
DemocratsintheHouse[ofRepresentatives].โ http://www.dccc.org/pages/about.

The Subpoena requests documents that evidence the DCCCโs involvement in the Illinois

behind the First Amendment, and the law (including the cases relied on by the DCCC) does not
allowthemtodoso. TheDCCCโsclaimof FirstAmendmentprotections mustfail.

Concerns.
In order to make its fundamentally flawed First Amendment argument, the DCCC

efforts to recruit candidates to run against Plaintiffsโ (Opp. at 7). Indeed, nowhere does the
subpoena request any of the types of materials the DCCC highlights as sensitiveโthe subpoena
does not request documents regarding election analysis, campaign strategy, internal DCCC
strategy, membership lists, or any information about private individuals. On the contrary,
Plaintiffs have made a confined request for documents related only to the DCCCโs involvement
in the fundamentally public process of redistricting in Illinois. The request is limited in both
subject matter and time. Moreover, counsel for the Plaintiffs reiterated the limited nature of the
information sought to counsel for the DCCC before filing this motion specifically to respond to

associational mission to recruit and support Democratic candidates for the U.S. House of
Representatives.โ Opp. at 12. On the contrary, Plaintiffs only seek information about the
DCCCโs influence on the state legislature and other public officials in Illinois in drawing the

The DCCC hangs its hat on the assertion that the First Amendment privilege extends
beyond membership lists. Opp. at 10. But there is no denying that exposure of a groupโs
members and supporters, and the effect of that exposure on the membersโ associational rights, is
the fundamental harm the privilege aims to protect. See NAACP v. Alabama, 357 U.S. 449, 462
(1958) (Supreme Court recognizes the โvital relationship between freedom to associate and
privacy in oneโs associations.โ). As demonstrated by several cases cited by the DCCC, the
concern withexposingmembershiporsupporters remains the animatingforcebehindrecognition
oftheprivilege. See, e.g.,IntโlActionCenter.,207 F.R.D. at2 (informationaboutparticipantsor
potential participants at protest is โexactly the kind of information the First Amendment is
designed to protectโ); Britt v. Superior Court, 20 Cal. 3d 844, 852 (Cal. 1978) (โIn compelling
the wholesale disclosure of private association affiliations and activities, the challenged
discovery order works an unconstitutional infringement of First Amendment rights.โ); Wilkinson
v. F.B.I, 111 F.R.D. 432, 436 (C.D. Cal. 1986) (โA review of the cases applying the privilege
11

reveals that in each case the discovery that was subject to enhanced First Amendment scrutiny
wasaspecificrequestforagroupโs membershiplistorlistoffinancialcontributors.โ).
The DCCCโs argument fails, however, because Plaintiffs simply have not asked for and
are not interested in this kind of information. The Subpoena does not seek donor lists,
membership lists, or any information about the DCCCโs so-called โadherents.โ See Mook Decl.
at 2. Plaintiffs seek nothing more than information about the DCCCโs role in the entirely
external activity of drawing a congressional redistricting Plan in concert with the Illinois
legislatureโa process that is fundamentally public and which the DCCC chose to insert itself
into. Having gotten itself involved in this publicprocess, the DCCC cannot now hide behind the
First Amendment. Moreover, the DCCCโs involvement was with third party public figures; it

B. PlaintiffsโSubpoenaWillNotCauseAโChillingEffect.โ
The DCCC cannot establish a First Amendment harm for another reason: its assertion of
a chilling effect (Opp. at 12, Mook Decl. at 3) simply is not credible. See New York State Natโl
Assoc. for Women v. Terry, 886 F.2d 1339, 1355 (2d cir. 1989) (compelling discovery where
defendant could not explain how requests would actually interfere with First Amendment
activities). TheDCCC cannot plausiblycontend that โenforcementof the discoveryrequests will
result in (1) harassment, membership withdrawal, or discouragement of new members, or other
consequences which objectively suggest an impact on, or chilling of, the membersโ associational
rights.โ Perry, 591 F.3d at 1160 (internal quotations omitted). As established repeatedly, the
information sought has nothing to do with the DCCCโs members or core membership and in no

Case:C 1a:s1e1 -1c:v1-10-5m0c6-50 0D5o1c4u-mDeAnRt  #  :D 9o0c-u1m Feilnetd 1: 31 0  / 2F4il/e1d1  0P9a/g2e9 /5151  o  fP 1a4g8e  P1a4g oefI D24 #:912
Moreover, as explained above (at 11-12), a First Amendment privilege exists to protect
โthe vital relationship between freedom to associate and privacy in oneโs associations.โ Intโl
Union v. Natโl RighttoWorkLegal Defenseand Educ. Foundโn,Inc., 590 F.2d 1139, 1152 (D.C.
Cir. 1978) (citing NAACP v. Alabama, 357 U.S. 449, 462 (1958)) (emphasis added). The
reasoning behind the privilege is that โpublic identification of individuals who never intended
theirparticipation in First Amendment activityto thrust theminto theharsh glare of thelimelight
is calculated to chill future political dissent and discourage participation in other protest
activity.โ Intโl Action Center, 207 F.R.D. at 3-4. It is exposure of association that is behind the
so-called chillingeffectofcompliancewithdiscovery. See,e.g.,Uphaus v. Wyman,360 U.S.72,
78 (1959) (interest at stake was associational privacy); Superior Court of San Diego County v.
San Diego Unified Port Dist., 574 Pac. 2d 766, 768 (Cal. 1978) (โintrusion into associational
privacyโ is what the First Amendment privilege prevents); Fed. Election Commโn v. Machinists
Non-Partisan Political League, 655 F.2d 380, (D.D.C. 1981) (โ[F]irst [A]mendment interest in
privacyofpoliticalassociationโthreatenedbysubpoena).
In a different context, a claim about the expectation of privacy of an interest groupโs
members might have some relevancy; here, with the DCCC, that argument is entirely specious.
The DCCCโs membership consists of public officials, namely Democrat congresspersons, whose
political associations are well known. The DCCC describes itself as โthe official campaign arm
of the Democrats in the House [of Representatives].โ http://www.dccc.org/pages/about
(emphasis added). In its own words, the DCCC is โ[o]rganized and operated by Democratic
members of the House of Representatives.โ See FEC Advisory Op. 1985-14 attached hereto as
Exhibit D. Like all public office holders, Democratic members of the House of Representatives
have willingly stepped into โharsh glare of the limelightโ and opened their political associations
13

Case:C 1a:s1e1 -1c:v1-10-5m0c6-50 0D5o1c4u-mDeAnRt  #  :D 9o0c-u1m Feilnetd 1: 31 0  / 2F4il/e1d1  0P9a/g2e9 /5161  o  fP 1a4g8e  P1a5g oefI D24 #:913
to public scrutiny. Because of this clear willingness to engage in political activity in the most
public way possible, the contention that such public figures will be discouraged or โchilledโโ
thattheymight actuallybecome reluctant to beDemocraticCongresspersonsโis laughable. The
DCCCcannotclaimprivilegebased merelyona FirstAmendment interest inassociating. Asthe
DCCC itself concedes (Opp. at 11), it must demonstrate harm to that interest, and this it cannot
do.
The DCCCโs reliance on Wyoming is misplaced in this regard as well. The groups
asserting a First Amendment interest in that case were environmental organizations consisting of
private citizens, not public officials. Wyoming, 208 F.R.D. at 451. Unlike the members of the
DCCC, members of those groups had not willingly exposed their political activities to public
view. The DCCC is not the Heritage Forest Campaign, id., nor is it ProtectMarriage.comโYes
on 8, Perry, 591 F.3d at 1147, and it is certainly not the NAACPโs Alabama affiliate in 1958,
NAACP, 357 U.S. at 451. The District of Columbia Circuit recognized decades ago that โthe
argument in favor of upholdingthe claim of privilege will ordinarily grow stronger as the danger
to rights of expression and association increases.โ Black Panther Party v. Smith, 661 F.2d 1243,
1267 (1981). Here, the DCCCโs cry of โchillโโmade in a declaration from a highly public
figure in the world of Democrat politics6โshows the argument at its weakest. The DCCC does
6 DCCC employee Robert E. Mook, Executive Director, although not a Congressman, is a
highlypublic figure who, according to the Washington Post, took over as โthe head of the House
Democratsโ campaign arm for the 2012 election.โ See http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-
dyn/content/article/2010/12/05/AR2010120504745.html. The DCCCโs own December 6, 2010
press release details Mr. Mookโs high profile political activities, including that โMook served as
the DCCCโs Political Director since the beginning of 2009. In that capacity he oversaw
candidate recruitment, campaign planning and strategy. Before joining the committee, he
managed Senator Jeanne Shaheenโs (NH) successful 2008 campaign for the United States
Senate. Mook also previously worked for then-Senator Hillary Clintonโs presidential campaign
where he was successful winning races as State Director in Nevada, Ohio, and Indiana. During
the 2004 cycle, Mook successfully oversaw the Wisconsin GOTV program for then Presidential
14

Case:C 1a:s1e1 -1c:v1-10-5m0c6-50 0D5o1c4u-mDeAnRt  #  :D 9o0c-u1m Feilnetd 1: 31 0  / 2F4il/e1d1  0P9a/g2e9 /5171  o  fP 1a4g8e  P1a6g oefI D24 #:914
not need, and cannotclaim, theprotectionof the First Amendmentโcertainlynotin this instance
where the actual requests in the Subpoena do not seek any information about the DCCCโs
membershipordonorlists.
C. Even If First Amendment Rights Are Implicated, Production Of The
DCCCโSResponsiveDocumentsIs Warranted.
Even if the DCCC had a colorable claim that its First Amendment interests are
threatenedโwhich it does notโPlaintiffs nonetheless should be permitted discoverybecause the
documents at issue in this case directly go to the โheart of the lawsuit.โ Wyoming, 208 F.R.D. at
455. Plaintiffsโ Complaint alleges that the Plan intentionally dilutes the votes of Latinos, enacts
an unconstitutional racial gerrymander, and engages in blatant partisan gerrymandering. On
information and belief, the DCCC, with and through its Illinois congressional members and its
agents, influenced the creation of the map that was eventually adopted by the Illinois General
Assembly. The intent of the DCCC thus became the intent of the Illinois legislature. The goals,
considerations, and motivations that influenced the DCCC in creating the map therefore are
critical to establishing that that the Plan was intended to disenfranchise Latino and Republican
voters in Illinois. See, e.g., Village of Arlington Heights v. Metro. Hous. Dev. Corp., 429 U.S.
252, 268 (1977) (recognizing that legislators โmight be called to the stand at trial to testify
concerning the purpose of the official actionโ); Rodriguez v. Pataki, 280 F. Supp. 2d 89, 102
(S.D.N.Y. 2003) (โWhile evidence of discriminatory animus may not be an essential element of
all of the plaintiffsโ claims, it certainly is something that can be considered in deciding whether
the . . . redistricting plans pass judicial muster.โ). United States v. Irvin, 127 F.R.D. 169, 171-
nominee Senator John Kerry.โ See http://dccc.org/blog/entry/dccc_chairman_steve_israel
names_robby_mook_dccc_executive_director/.
15

Case:C 1a:s1e1 -1c:v1-10-5m0c6-50 0D5o1c4u-mDeAnRt  #  :D 9o0c-u1m Feilnetd 1: 31 0  / 2F4il/e1d1  0P9a/g2e9 /5181  o  fP 1a4g8e  P1a7g oefI D24 #:915
173 (C.D. Cal. 1989) (โevidence concerning the intent with which the [redistricting body]
adoptedtheplanand rejectedcertainalternatives,โishighly-relevant).
The centrality of the evidence requested here makes this case very different from
Wyoming. There, the court found that the documents were irrelevant to the State of Wyomingโs
claims under the Federal Advisory Committee Act (โFACAโ). Wyoming, 208 F.R.D. at 453.
Under that statute, what mattered for the stateโs claim was the degree of control the government
exercised over the interest groups, and the interest groupsโ activities had no impact on whether
the defendant violated FACA. Id. at 454. Here, the situation is reversed: it is the DCCCโs
control over the Illinois mapping process that is central to the litigation. Thus, Plaintiffs must be
allowedto gather evidencerelatingtothatinfluence.
Moreover, and again in contrast to Wyoming, these documents cannot be obtained from
another source, with or without reasonable efforts. Plaintiffs have sued the Illinois State Board
of Elections and its members (collectively โSBEโ) to enjoin their use of the Proposed
Congressional Plan in the upcoming 2012 congressional elections. But, unlike the DCCC, the
SBE has admitted that it, not surprisingly, had no role in the development of the Plan and
therefore possesses no documents evidencing any intent to dilute the voting strength of Illinois
Latinos and/or Republicans. Thus, unlike Wyoming, where party discovery clearly was a
superioralternativetothecontestedsubpoena, seeid.at455,nopartyinthis casecanprovidethe
evidencethatis intheDCCCโspossession.
The DCCCโs reliance on American Fed. of Labor and Congress of Indus. Orgs. v. Fed.
Election Commโn, 333 F.3d 168 (D.C. Cir. 2003) also is misplaced. American Federation
involved an FEC regulation requiring disclosure to the public of FEC investigatory files. Id. at
170. The DCCC is well aware that nothing like that kind of disclosure is contemplated by
16

Case:C 1a:s1e1 -1c:v1-10-5m0c6-50 0D5o1c4u-mDeAnRt  #  :D 9o0c-u1m Feilnetd 1: 31 0  / 2F4il/e1d1  0P9a/g2e9 /5191  o  fP 1a4g8e  P1a8g oefI D24 #:916
Plaintiffsโ Subpoena. The DCCC is required only to turn over its responsive documents to
Plaintiffs, who repeatedlyhaveexpressed theirwillingness to abidebyan agreed-upon protective
order. See Mot. ยถ 32. See also Natโl Org. for Marriage v. McKee, 723 F. Supp. 2d 236, 240-41
(D.Me.2010)(alleged chillingeffectnegatedbyprotectiveorder).
IV. Plaintiffs Clearly Have Established A Substantial Need For The Requested
Documents.
The DCCC asserts no sound basis for claiming that its records constitute material akin to
trade secrets. โCourts typically consider two factors in analyzing Rule 45 cases, beginning with
whether the release of the information would unfairly harm the disclosing partyโs ability to
compete in the marketplace.โ Albany Molecular Research, 274 F.R.D. at 25. Notwithstanding
the DCCCโs mischaracterization of Plaintiffsโ requests, Plaintiffs do not seek material regarding
the DCCCโs strategies with respect to competing in the 2012 congressional electionsโin Illinois
or anywhere else. Plaintiffsโ Subpoena only seeks a narrow set of documents directly related to
the DCCCโs role in the creation of the Plan at issue in the underlying action. The DCCC has not
established, as it must, how production of those documents will work a competitive harm on the
DCCC. Therefore these materials should not be considered confidential information under Rule
45.
Because harm to a competitive position is the central concern, the second factor a court
considers is whether the information is being disclosed to a competitor. Falicia v. Advanced
Tenant Services, Inc., 235 F.R.D. 5, 7 (D.D.C. 2006). Competitive interests are not implicated
by the information requested by the Subpoena, and the authority relied upon by the DCCC is
inapplicable. See Echostar Commcโns Corp. v. News Corp. Ltd., 180 F.R.D. 391, 395 (D. Colo.
1998) (โNo one disputes that Echostar is a competitor of the non-parties.โ); see also Educ.
Logistics, Inc. v. Laidlaw Transit, Inc., 2011 WL 1348401, at *2 (N.D. Tex. Apr. 8, 2011)
17

Case:C 1a:s1e1 -1c:v1-10-5m0c6-50 0D5o1c4u-mDeAnRt  #  :D 9o0c-u1m Feilnetd 1: 31 0  / 2F4il/e1d1  0P9a/g2e9 /6101  o  fP 1a4g8e  P1a9g oefI D24 #:917
(requesting party was a โdirect competitorโ of the subpoena target). The DCCCโs competitor is
the National Republican Congressional Committee (โNRCCโ), a non-party to this or the
underlying action. SeeOpp. at12,17. Thefact thatPlaintiff Congressman John Shimkus also is
an officer of the NRCC is irrelevant; the NRCC is not a party to this or the underlying action,
andthereforeno informationwill bedisclosed to it. Moreover, to alleviate theDCCCโs apparent
concerns in this regard (see Opp. at 1, 2, 5, 17; Mook Decl. ยถ 4), Plaintiffs have made clear their
willingness to enter into a reasonable protective order to safeguard the DCCCโs documents.
Mot.ยถ32; seealso AlbanyMolecular Research, 274 F.R.D. at26 (โTheexistence of aprotective
order weighs against quashing the subpoena on commercial information grounds because the
protective order is designed to protect and prevent public disclosure of confidential and sensitive
businessinformation,likethatpotentiallyatissuehere.โ).
Even if the DCCC had a cognizable trade secret or confidentiality interest, Plaintiffs
plainly have a โsubstantial need for the . . . material that cannot be otherwise met without undue
hardship.โ FED. R. CIV. P. 45(c)(3)(C)(i). To show substantial need, the requesting party must
demonstrate that โobtaining the information is both relevant and necessaryโ to the underlying
litigation. Falicia, 235 F.R.D. at 7. See also Compaq Computer Corp. v. Packard Bell
Electronics,Inc.,163 F.R.D.329,338(N.D.Cal. 1995)(โ[D]iscoveryisvirtuallyalwaysordered
once the movant has established that the secret information is [both] relevant and necessary.โ).
Plaintiffs amply have demonstrated that the requested documents are highly relevant to their
case. Fundamentally, now two members of Congress have testified under oath that two different
Democratic lawmakers, one a Congressman and the other the President of the Illinois State
Senate, informed themthattheDCCC and/orone ofits agents drew the map comprisingthe Plan
Plaintiffs challenge in the underlying action. Nowhere in its Opposition does the DCCC deny
18

Case:C 1a:s1e1 -1c:v1-10-5m0c6-50 0D5o1c4u-mDeAnRt  #  :D 9o0c-u1m Feilnetd 1: 31 0  / 2F4il/e1d1  0P9a/g2e9 /6111  o  fP 1a4g8e  P2a0g oefI D24 #:918
this. Thus, the DCCCโs documents relating to the drafting process are not merely relevant but
essential to showingthe intent ofDCCC and of Illinois legislators with whomtheycooperated as
to the constitutionally infirm Plan. Plaintiffsโ Subpoena requests therefore are โprobing the
precise topicโ of how the Plan was created and why. Athridge v. Aetna Cas. and Sur. Co., 184
F.R.D. 200, 210 (D.D.C. 1998). Documents responsive to the Subpoena clearly exist as the
DCCC admits (Opp. at 18), Plaintiffs have established a legitimate use for such documents in
that they are central to proving the intent behind the Plan, and the narrowness of the Subpoenaโs
requests demonstratethat this is not afishing expedition. SeeCusumano v. Microsoft Corp., 162
F.3d708,716(1stCir.1998).
Furthermore, there are no other easier or less intrusive ways for Plaintiffs to obtain
essential and admissible direct evidence of intent other than from the very party who created the
Plan. See Kulzer v. Esschem, Inc., 390 F. Appโx 88, 93 (3d Cir. 2010) (substantial need for
confidential information demonstrated where respondent was only available source of
information). Other partiesโ testimony about what the DCCC and its agents did or did not do
concerningthe Plan is of course hearsay and likely not admissible. Consequently, the best, most
relevant, and admissible source of evidence about what the DCCC intended concerning the
drafting of the Plan comes from the DCCC itself.7 Thus, compelling the DCCCโs production of
documents responsive to the Subpoena is necessary to provide evidence for Plaintiffs to prove
that the individuals and entities who drew the Plan intended to disenfranchise Latino and
7 The DCCC has argued that the better alternative source for the information is the Illinois
legislature. However, as the DCCC well knows, individual legislators and their staff have
asserted blanket, absolute legislative immunity from discovery and asserted that the documents
can be obtained from the DCCC. Moreover, even if the Plaintiffs are able to obtain some
information from the Illinois legislature, any such evidence or testimony about the DCCCโs
actions will likely face a hearsay challenge. As such, the DCCC is, of course, the best source of
admissibleevidenceaboutitsownactions indraftingthePlan.
19

Case:C 1a:s1e1 -1c:v1-10-5m0c6-50 0D5o1c4u-mDeAnRt  #  :D 9o0c-u1m Feilnetd 1: 31 0  / 2F4il/e1d1  0P9a/g2e9 /6121  o  fP 1a4g8e  P2a1g oefI D24 #:919
Republican voters in Illinois. And, it makes the most sense to obtain documents related to these
communications directly from the source. For these reasons, Plaintiffs plainlyhave a substantial
needforthedocumentsrequestedbytheSubpoena.
V. The DCCC Is Not Excused From Compliance With The Federal Rules Of Civil
Procedure.
A. TheDCCCโs AttemptToSealIts PrivilegeLogIsImproper.
The DCCCโs Opposition asserts that the entirety of the nearly 800 pages of responsive
material is subject to privilege and has been identified in a privilege log. Opp. at 18. If the
DCCC truly considers these documents privileged, Rule 45 mandates that the DCCC must
describe the nature of the documents not produced or disclosed and do so in a manner that,
withoutrevealinginformation itselfprivileged or protected, will enableotherparties to assess the
claim. FED. R. CIV. P. 45(d)(2)(A); see also In re Apollo Group, Inc. Sec. Litig., 2007 WL
778653, at *8 (D.D.C. March 12, 2007) (โTo the extent the DOE maintains that it is not required
toproducethedocumentssoughtintheAmended Subpoenaonthegrounds ofvariousprivileges,
the DOE must comply with its obligations under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 45(d)(2) and
produce a privilege log that allows Apollo and the Court to assess the validity of the claimed
privileges.โ). Rather than provide Plaintiffs with a copy of the log as is its duty, the DCCC filed
a motion for leave to file its privilege log under seal. See Opp. at 18. The DCCC has cited no
case law in support of its extraordinary request. In response, Plaintiffs have filed an Opposition
to the DCCCโs Motion For Leave To File Privilege Log Under Seal, which is incorporated by
referenceas thoughfullysetforthherein.
B. TheDCCCStillRefusesToArticulateSpecificObjections.
As set forth in Plaintiffโs Motion to Compel, Rule 34 โplainly states that objections to
requests for production must be made on an individual basis.โ Lurensky v. Wellinghoff, 258
20

Case:C 1a:s1e1 -1c:v1-10-5m0c6-50 0D5o1c4u-mDeAnRt  #  :D 9o0c-u1m Feilnetd 1: 31 0  / 2F4il/e1d1  0P9a/g2e9 /6131  o  fP 1a4g8e  P2a2g oefI D24 #:920
F.R.D. 27, 30 (D.D.C. 2009). And โ[u]nder Rule 34, failure to make particularized objections to
document requests constitutes a waiver of those objections.โ Sabol v. Brooks, 469 F. Supp. 2d
324, 328 (D. Md. 2006) (ordering non-party to produce documents requested by a Rule 45
subpoena); see also FED.R.CIV.P. 34 (b)(2)(B) (โFor each itemor category, the response must .
. . state an objection to the request, including the reasons.โ) (emphasis added). Rather than
attempt to remedy its failure to comply with the specificity requirements of Rule 34, the DCCC
broadlyassertsthat โtherewas nothingtobe gainedbyrepeatingDCCCโsobjections ... foreach
request.โ Opp. at 20. Plaintiffs respectfully submit that, despite the DCCCโs assertion
otherwise, the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure are not โsenseless processโ (id. at 20), and the
DCCCshouldbeboundbytheirrequirements.
CONCLUSION
WHEREFORE, for the foregoing reasons, the Court should grant Plaintiffsโ Motion to
Compel and order the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee to comply with
Plaintiffsโ subpoena within ten (10) days and award Plaintiffs their attorneysโ fees and other
costs associated with Plaintiffsโ Motion To Compel Democratic Congressional Campaign
Committee ToComplyWith SubpoenaSeekingThirdPartyDiscovery.
21
