documents.title: Defendants' Motion to Dismiss Counts V and VI of Plaintiffs' Amended Complaint
documents.text:
Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 122 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 1 of 12 PageID #:2483
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF ILLINOIS, EASTERN DIVISION 
 
COMMITTEE FOR A FAIR AND BALANCED  )   
MAP, et al.,            ) 
              ) 
      Plaintiffs,      ) 
              )  Case No. 11-C-5065 
    v.           ) 
              )  Hon. John D. Tinder 
ILLINOIS STATE BOARD OF ELECTIONS,  )  Hon. Joan H. Lefkow 
et al.,              )  Hon. Robert L. Miller, Jr. 
              )  (3-judge court convened     
Defendants.      )  pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 2284) 
   
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION TO DISMISS COUNTS V AND VI OF  
PLAINTIFFSโ AMENDED COMPLAINT 
 
  Defendants, by their attorney Lisa Madigan, Attorney General for the State of 
Illinois,  respectfully  move  to  dismiss  Counts  V  and  VI  of  Plaintiffsโ  Amended 
Complaint.  For the following reasons, these claims should be dismissed pursuant to 
Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6). 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
  Plaintiffsโ original Complaint contained two counts alleging an unconstitutional 
partisan  gerrymander  in  violation  of  the  14th  Amendment  (Count  VI)  and  the  First 
Amendment (Count V).  This Courtโs November 1, 2011 Opinion and Order dismissed 
both.  In its Opinion, this Court concluded โ[t]he Committeeโs Fourteenth Amendment 
partisan gerrymandering claim must be dismissed because, with no workable standard yet 
in existence, the court canโt say that its allegations give rise to a plausible claim upon 
which relief can be granted.โ DE#98; Courtโs November 1, 2011 Opinion and Order 
(โMemo. Op.โ), p. 19.  Recognizing that the Supreme Court has rejected every proposed 
standard, this Court noted that, โ[w]e surmise that amendment might be futile in light of 
todayโs understanding of the law under the Equal Protection Clause.โ Id.  Nevertheless, 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 122 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 2 of 12 PageID #:2484
the Court provided the Committee an opportunity โto amend its complaint in an effort to 
articulate a workable and reliable standard for adjudicating their partisan gerrymandering 
claim and sufficient factual allegations to demonstrate plausibility.โ  Id. at 20. 
  In addressing the First Amendment claim contained in Count V, on the other 
hand, this Court found that the โcomplaint falls to a different obstacle.โ  Id.  In dismissing 
Count V, this Court found that โ[t]he Committeeโs complaint doesnโt make plausible a 
finding that the 2011 Map infringes Republican votersโ rights to associate with each other 
or with anyone else, or a finding that the 2011 Map burdens Republican votersโ rights of 
free expression, or that the 2011 Map affects Republican votersโ rights to petition the 
government.โ Id. at 21.  The Court rejected Plaintiffโs allegations that the Redistricting 
Plan โwill make it more difficult for Republican voters to elect Republican candidatesโ 
because โthat doesnโt implicate a First Amendment right.โ Id.  This Courtโs discussion of 
Count V did not include a similar invitation to amend. 
Undeterred,  Plaintiffsโ  Amended  Complaint  contains  both  a  Fourteenth 
Amendment claim (Count VI) and a First Amendment claim (Count V).  Both of these 
amended partisan gerrymandering claims should be dismissed because, like their first 
failed effort, Plaintiffs do not articulate any โworkable and reliable standardโ for judging 
an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander.  Having failed to articulate a โworkable and 
reliable standard,โ Defendants and the Court therefore are left with no way to assess 
whether Plaintiffsโ allegations are โplausible.โ  
  Count VI, under the Fourteenth Amendment, should  be dismissed because  it 
simply restates proposed bases for partisan gerrymander claims that have already been 
expressly rejected by the Supreme Court.  Count V, under the First Amendment, should 
2 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 122 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 3 of 12 PageID #:2485
be  dismissed  for  two  reasons.    First,  while  this  Courtโs  November  1,  2011  Order 
permitted an amendment to the Complaint regarding the 14th Amendment claims, it is 
less clear an amended First Amendment claim would be countenanced.  Id. at 20-22.  
Second, Count V articulates verbatim the same standard as Count VI and, thus, should be 
dismissed for the same reasons. 
II.  ARGUMENT 
A.  The Partisan Gerrymander Claim under the Equal Protection Clause 
in  Count  VI  Should  Be  Dismissed  Because  Plaintiffsโ  Proposed 
Standard has been Considered and Rejected by the Supreme Court. 
 
  Pursuant  to  this  Courtโs  November  1,  2011  Order,  Plaintiffs  amended  their 
Complaint to include a proposed standard for measuring partisan gerrymandering claims.  
Going beyond the Courtโs Order, however, the Amended Complaint also changes the 
districts that Plaintiffs claim were politically  gerrymandered.  The  initial Complaint 
alleged that Districts 3, 11, and 13 were politically gerrymandered, but the Amended 
Complaint drops the challenge to District 3 and adds a new challenge to District 17. 
Amend. Comp. ยถ139.  Needless to say, bringing a new challenge to a new district the 
week before trial, after the close of discovery, and after all of the experts have submitted 
their reports and have been deposed, is unfair and prejudicial.  
  Regardless  of  which  districts  are  challenged,  however,  Plaintiffsโ  proposed 
standard is neither โworkableโ nor โreliableโ and has been rejected by the Supreme 
Court.  First, Plaintiffsโ proposed standard purports to have โan intent requirement and an 
effect  requirement.โ    Amend.  Comp.,  ยถ  140.    This  two-pronged  (intent  and  effect) 
standard is essentially the same as the one proposed twenty-five years ago in Davis v. 
Bandemer, 478 U.S. 109, 133 (1986), measuring plaintiffsโ โdirect or indirect influence 
3 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 122 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 4 of 12 PageID #:2486
on the elections of the state legislature as a whole.โ  The proposed standard was expressly 
rejected by the Supreme Court in Vieth v. Jubelirer, 541 U.S. 267, 283-284 (2004) (โthis 
standard  was  misguided  when  proposed,  has  not  been  improved  in  subsequent 
application, and is not even defended before us today by the appellants, we decline to 
affirm it as a constitutional requirement.โ). 
  Plaintiffs argue that the first element of their purported standardโintentโcan be 
shown by โdirect or circumstantial proof that the Stateโs mapmakers created one or more 
congressional  districts  with  the  predominant  intent  to  secure  partisan  advantage.โ  
Amend. Comp., ยถ 141 (emphasis added).  However, in Vieth, the Supreme Court flatly 
rejected a proposed โpredominant intentโ standard that was worded essentially the same 
way as the one proposed here.  Vieth, 541 U.S. at 284 (proposed โintent standardโ would 
require plaintiff to โโshow that the mapmakers acted with a predominant intent to achieve 
partisan  advantage,โ  which  can  be  shown  โby  direct  evidence  or  by  circumstantial 
evidence that other neutral and legitimate redistricting criteria were subordinated to the 
goal of achieving partisan advantage.โโ).  The Court rejected this proposed standard 
because: 
Vague as the โpredominant motivationโ test might be when 
used to evaluate single districts,  it all  but evaporates when 
applied  statewide.  Does  it  mean,  for  instance,  that  partisan 
intent must outweigh all other goalsโcontiguity, compactness, 
preservation of neighborhoods, etc.โ statewide? And how is 
the statewide โoutweighingโ to be determined? 
 
Id. at 285 (emphasis in original).  Moreover, not only has the Supreme Court expressly 
rejected Plaintiffsโ proposed โpredominant intentโ standard, it has even gone so far as to 
reject a proposed โsole motivationโ standard.  League of United Latin American Citizens 
v. Perry, 548 U.S. 399, 418-420 (2006) (โLULACโ) (โa successful claim attempting to 
4 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 122 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 5 of 12 PageID #:2487
identify unconstitutional acts of partisan gerrymandering must do what appellantsโ sole-
motivation theory explicitly disavows: show a burden, as measured by a reliable standard, 
on the complainantsโ representational rights.โ).  In LULAC, the Court rejected the sole 
motivation  standard:    โThe  [Texas  state]  legislature  does  seem  to  have  decided  to 
redistrict with the sole purpose of achieving a Republican congressional majority, but 
partisan aims did not guide every line it drew.โ Id. at 417. 
  The  Vieth  Court  not  only  rejected  the  โpredominant  intentโ  standard  for 
measuring a statewide redistricting plan, but also as applied to individual districts.  Vieth, 
541  U.S.  at  285  (because  โpolitical  entitiesโ  are  responsible  for  redistricting, 
โunsurprisingly that turns out to be root-and-branch a matter of politicsโ).  The Supreme 
Court  rejected  a  comparison  to  racial  gerrymandering  because,  unlike  racial 
gerrymandering claims, โthe fact that partisan districting is a lawful and common practice 
means that there is almost always room for an election-impeding lawsuit contending that 
partisan advantage was the predominant motivation.โ  Id. at 286.  This is exactly the 
situation presented here:  Plaintiffs seek, through this litigation, to impede the upcoming 
election due to the โlawful and common practiceโ of political line drawing. 
  Plaintiffsโ โeffectsโ element, the second prong of their proposed standard, fares no 
better than their proposed intent element.  Plaintiffs argue that a redistricting plan has an 
unconstitutional effect where it is the case:  
(1) that the Proposed Congressional Plan increases the number of 
districts that favor Democrats by at least 10% according to an 
accepted  measure  of  partisan  voting;  (2)  that  the  Proposed 
Congressional  Plan  keeps  at  least  10%  more  constituents  of 
Democratic incumbents in the same district as their representative 
than it does constituents of Republican incumbents; and (3) that at 
least  one  of  the  districts  created  with  the  intent  to  advantage 
Democrats is among the districts that contributes to the proof of 
5 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 122 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 6 of 12 PageID #:2488
elements 1 and 2.  
 
Amend. Comp., ยถ 142.  These proposed measures of purported unconstitutional effect are 
obviously unworkable.   
  As to the proposed first element:  What does it mean to โfavorโ Democrats?  By 
how much does the district have to โfavorโ Democrats?  Does a district that shifts from 
49.99 % Democratic to 50.01% count?  What if it switches back after the next election?  
How many election results  need to be reviewed to constitute sufficient evidence of 
partisanship?   In addition, it is unclear whether and how this element can take into 
account independent or new voters in a district. 
  Moreover, as to their proposed first element, Plaintiffs argue the partisanship 
โfavorโ must be by an โacceptedโ measure.  By whom, Plaintiffs do not say.  What if 
there is more than one measure, and they conflict?  Although they have not offered an 
expert witness on their partisanship claims, Plaintiffs make reference to the Cook Partisan 
Voting Index, which measures partisanship in presidential elections. Amend. Comp., ยถ 
75, fn. 10.  Needless to say, this measure changes from election to election, and it 
includes only presidential elections, omitting Congressional midterm elections and any 
other electoral contests.  Recent history demonstrates that the Partisan Indices from the 
2008 Presidential Election had little predictive value relative to the November 2010 
Congressional elections.  As the Supreme Court noted, the difficulty with these so-called 
indices is: 
a person's politics is rarely as readily discernibleโand never as 
permanently discernibleโas a person's race. Political affiliation is 
not an immutable characteristic, but may shift from one election to 
the next; and even within a given election, not all voters follow the 
party line. We dare say (and hope) that the political party which 
puts forward an utterly incompetent candidate will lose even in its 
6 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 122 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 7 of 12 PageID #:2489
registration stronghold. These facts make it impossible to assess 
the effects of partisan gerrymandering, to fashion a standard for 
evaluating a violation, and finally to craft a remedy. 
 
Vieth, 541 U.S. at 287 (emphasis in original).  It is impossible for any party to gauge with 
certainty whether individual votersโ partisan preferences will change with any future 
election, which makes such indices improper indicators of voter choice.    
  Next, Plaintiffs argue the number of Democratic โfavoredโ districts must increase 
by 10% in order to show an unconstitutional partisan effect.  That begs the question:  
10% of what?  Does that refer to total districts or only Democratic Districts?  Because 
Illinois has eight Democratic Representatives, an increase of one Democratic โfavoredโ 
district would be unconstitutional (going from 8 to 9 is a 12.5% increase) under the 
Plaintiffsโ proposed standard.  Imagine a state with ten districts (five favor Democrats, 
and five favor Republicans) that, like Illinois has for two consecutive decades, loses a 
district to reapportionment.  What then?  That state arguably cannot mathematically draw 
a constitutional plan because the loss of one side or the other will increase partisan 
advantage by 20%. 
  Further, Plaintiffs argue that an unconstitutional effect is apparently shown when 
the Plan โkeepsโ 10% more Democrats in the โsame district as their representativeโ than 
โit does constituents of Republican incumbents.โ  Amend. Comp., ยถ 142.  The more one 
reads this allegation, the less sense it makes.  Would it mean that a given map keeps 10% 
more Democrats with their incumbent legislator than it keeps Republicans with their 
incumbent  legislator?    Does  that  count  everyone  or  only  Democrats  in  Democratic 
districts and Republicans in Republican districts?  Does it apply statewide?  If so, how?  
Is it just raw numbers or averages?  Does one count total population, VAP or CVAP, 
7 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 122 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 8 of 12 PageID #:2490
registered  voters  or  turnout?    If  partisanship  is,  as  the  Supreme  Court  says,  never 
permanently discernible for determining how people will vote, it is just as impossible to 
discern for purposes of determining things like district/constituent retention. 
  Plaintiffsโ proposed standard, because it depends on projecting a voterโs past 
partisan voting behavior into the future, is just as unmanageable as the standards rejected 
in Vieth.  Vieth, 541 U.S. at 288 (rejecting Plaintiffsโ proposed intent and effect standard 
as โnot judicially manageableโ because โ[t]o begin with, how is a partyโs majority status 
to be established?โ).  Similarly, the Vieth Court rejected Plaintiffsโ proposed standard 
because it attempted to use statewide partisanship indexes for legislative districts.  Id. 
(โMoreover, to think that majority status in statewide races establishes majority status for 
district contests, one would  have to believe that the only  factor determining  voting 
behavior at all levels is political affiliation. That is assuredly not true.โ). 
  Plaintiffsโ proposed standard is even further removed from legislative elections 
than the one rejected in Vieth.  These Plaintiffs apparently want to use a partisanship 
standard derived only from presidential elections, which is an even less reliable indicator 
of partisanship for district-level elections than statewide elections.  Moreover, they would 
have this Court use a โnational averageโ measure of partisanship.  Amend. Comp., fn. 10.  
In other words, the partisanship of Illinoisโs Congressional Districts is measured against a 
baseline that includes results from every other state.  What election returns in Montana, 
North Dakota, or Mississippi have to say about Illinoisโs districts, Plaintiffs do not say.  
Additionally, the Cook Partisan Voting Index is not a reliable indicator of Congressional 
election results in Illinois.  Prior to the 2010 midterms, the PVI favored Democrats in 10 
districts and ranked one district as evenly divided.  Yet Democrats won only 8 seats in 
8 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 122 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 9 of 12 PageID #:2491
the actual election. (Cook Political Report, Partisan Voting Index Districts of the 111th 
Congress, pp. 2A.4-2A.5, http://cookpolitical.com/sites/default/files/pvistate.pdf). 
  Plaintiffs  will  no  doubt  respond  that  their  proposal,  unlike  some  others,  is 
โeminently scientificโ with its different โelementsโ and โfactors.โ  See, e.g., Vieth, 541 
U.S. at 296.  However, as noted above, Plaintiffsโ proposed standard, just like every other 
 
proposal, is designed to measure โwhen political gerrymandering has gone too far.โ Id.  
The Supreme Court has rejected these multiple factor proposals because โ[i]t does not 
solve  that  problem  to  break  down  the  original  unanswerable  question  (How  much 
political  motivation  and  effect  is  too  much?)  into  four  more  discrete  but  equally 
unanswerable questions.โ Id. at 296-97. 
Furthermore,  in  Vieth,  the  Supreme  Court  not  only  rejected  the  standards 
mentioned above, but also a proposed โtotality of the circumstancesโ test.  Id. at 291.  
The  plurality  also  rejected  Justice  Stevensโ  proposed  use  of  racial  gerrymandering 
analysis (Id. at 293-294), Justice Souterโs proposed Title VII based standard (Id. at 295), 
and Justice Breyerโs proposed โunjustified entrenchmentโ standard.  Id. at 299.  Simply 
put,  โno  judicially  discernible  and  manageable  standards  for  adjudicating  political 
gerrymandering claims have emerged.โ Id. at 285. 
  The problems with Plaintiffsโ proposed standard are too many to mention in great 
detail, but they are similar to the very problems that caused the Supreme Court to reject 
every proposed standard that has been presented.  This proposed standard fares no better, 
and should, like all the others, be rejected.  Count VI should be dismissed. 
B.  Count  V  Should  Be  Dismissed  Because  Partisan  Gerrymandering 
Claims Do Not Implicate the First Amendment. 
 
   Count V should be dismissed for three reasons.  First, as noted above, this Courtโs 
9 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 122 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 10 of 12 PageID #:2492
November 1, 2011 Order dismissed the First Amendment partisan gerrymandering claim 
but did not clearly invite an amendment to that count the same way the Court did with the 
Equal Protection claim.  Mem. Op., p. 20-22.  Second, Plaintiffsโ proposed standard for 
measuring  partisan  gerrymandering  claims  is,  verbatim,  the  same  as  the  one  they 
proposed  for  their  Equal  Protection  claim  and,  therefore,  is  both  unworkable  and 
unreliable for the same reasons discussed above.  See Section II.A, supra.  Finally, the 
Supreme Court and courts in this District, including this Court, have consistently ruled 
that partisan gerrymandering claims cannot plausibly implicate the First Amendment. 
  The  fact  that  Plaintiffsโ  proposed  standard  for  measuring  a  First  Amendment 
violation is exactly the same as their proposed Equal Protection standard is telling.  In 
Vieth, the Supreme Court expressly rejected the notion that a First Amendment analysis is 
the same as an Equal Protection one. Id. at 294.  Moreover, the Supreme Court also 
rejected the notion that partisan gerrymandering claims violate the First Amendment 
because  โa  First Amendment claim,  if  it were  sustained, would render unlawful all 
consideration  of  political  affiliation  in  districting,  just  as  it  renders  unlawful  all 
consideration of political  affiliation  in  hiring  for non-policy-level government jobs.โ 
Vieth, 541 U.S. at 294. 
  Recognizing this Supreme Court jurisprudence, courts in this judicial District have 
thrice dismissed First Amendment partisan gerrymandering claims in the last month 
alone.  First, there is this Courtโs initial ruling dismissing Count V in this matter:  โThe 
Committeeโs complaint contains a considerable number of allegations to the effect that 
the 2011 Map will make it more difficult for Republican voters to elect Republican 
candidates, but that doesnโt implicate a First Amendment right.โ  Memo. Op. at 21.  In 
10 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 122 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 11 of 12 PageID #:2493
addition, within the last two weeks, the three judge panel in this District that is hearing 
challenges to the Stateโs legislative redistricting plan has also dismissed, with prejudice, 
two separate First Amendment partisan gerrymander claims.  See Radogno v. Illinois 
State Bd. of Elections, 2011 WL 5025251, *8 (N.D. Ill. Oct. 21, 2011) (dismissing First 
Amendment  partisan  gerrymandering  claim,  reasoning  that  the  โeffects  of  political 
gerrymandering on the ability of a political party and its voters to elect a member of the 
party to a seat . . . implicates no recognized First Amendment rightโ); League of Women 
Voters v. Quinn, 2011 WL 5143044, *2 (N.D. Ill. Oct. 28, 2011) (rejecting plaintiffsโ 
First Amendment partisan gerrymander claim because โit brushes aside a critical first step 
to  bringing  a  content-based  First  Amendment  challenge:    the  challenged  law  must 
actually restrict some form of protected expression.โ). 
  In League of Women Voters, Plaintiffs brought a single count complaint asserting 
partisan gerrymandering under the First Amendment.  Id. at *1.  In short, Plaintiffs 
asserted that the use of political  data  in the redistricting process abridged the First 
Amendment.  Id.  In dismissing the Complaint with prejudice, the Court considered: 
Under the redistricting plan, are LWV's members being in 
any way prohibited from running for office, expressing their 
political views, endorsing and campaigning for their favorite 
candidates, voting for their preferred candidate, or otherwise 
influencing the political process through their expression? 
The answer is no.  
 
Id. at *3.  The same questions can be put to the Plaintiffs here.  The redistricting plan 
does not prohibit them from running for office, expressing their political views, endorsing 
and  campaigning  for  candidates,  voting  for  preferred  candidates,  or  influencing  the 
political process through their free expression.  Thus, the Supreme Court was correct 
when it concluded in Vieth that partisan gerrymanders do not raise First Amendment 
11 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 122 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 12 of 12 PageID #:2494
concerns, as was this District in Radogno and League of Women Voters..  Count V should 
now be dismissed with prejudice. 
 
  WHEREFORE, Defendants respectfully request that this Court dismiss Count V 
and Count VI of Plaintiffsโ Amended Complaint with prejudice. 
 
Date:  November 11, 2011      Respectfully submitted, 
 
            LISA MADIGAN,  
            Attorney General for the State of Illinois 
 
 
                           /s/ Brent D. Stratton      
              Attorney for Defendants                           
                         
 
Brent D. Stratton 
Carl Bergetz  
Jon Rosenblatt 
Office of the Illinois Attorney General 
100 West Randolph, 12th Floor 
Chicago, Illinois 60601 
312-814-3000 
 
 
 
 
 
 
12

documents.title: Defendants' Answer to Amended Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
documents.text:
Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 1 of 35 PageID #:2497
   
  IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT   
FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF ILLINOIS 
EASTERN DIVISION 
 
COMMITTEE FOR A FAIR AND      ) 
BALANCED MAP, JUDY BIGGERT,    ) 
ROBERT J. DOLD, RANDY HULTGREN,   ) 
ADAM KINZINGER, DONALD MANZULLO,  ) 
PETER J. ROSKAM, BOBBY SCHILLING,  ) 
AARON SCHOCK, JOHN M. SHIMKUS, JOE  )  Case No. 11-C-5065 
WALSH, RALPH RANGEL, LOU      ) 
SANDOVAL, LUIS SANABRIA, MICHELLE  )  Hon. John D. Tinder 
CABALLERO, EDMUND BREZINSKI, and  )  Hon. Joan H. Lefkow 
LAURA WAXWEILER,        )  Hon. Robert L. Miller, Jr. 
              ) 
Plaintiffs,        ) 
v.              ) 
              ) 
ILLINOIS STATE BOARD OF ELECTIONS,  ) 
WILLIAM M. MCGUFFAGE, JESSE R.    ) 
SMART, BRYAN A. SCHNEIDER, BETTY J.  ) 
COFFRIN, HAROLD D. BYERS, JUDITH C.  ) 
RICE, CHARLES W. SCHOLZ, and ERNEST  ) 
L. GOWEN,            ) 
              ) 
Defendants.        ) 
 
DEFENDANTSโ ANSWER TO AMENDED COMPLAINT  
FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF  
 
 
Defendants  ILLINOIS  STATE  BOARD  OF  ELECTIONS,  WILLIAM  M. 
MCGUFFAGE,  JESSE  R.  SMART,  BRYAN  A.  SCHNEIDER,  BETTY  J.  COFFRIN, 
HAROLD  D.  BYERS,  JUDITH  C.  RICE,  CHARLES  W.  SCHOLZ,  and  ERNEST  L. 
GOWEN (collectively, โthe Defendantsโ) hereby answer Plaintiffsโ Amended Complaint for 
Declaratory and Injunctive Relief: 
1.  Without any of the promised public hearings, the State of Illinois has adopted a 
new map for the  stateโs federal congressional districts (the  โProposed Congressional 
Planโ) that blatantly discriminates against Latino and Republican voters.1 As a result 
                                                
1 Images of the Proposed Congressional Planโtaken from the Illinois General Assemblyโs 
Website at http://www.ilga.gov/CongressionalDistrictMaps/Statewide%20View.pdg and at 
http://www.ilga.gov/CongressionalDistrictMaps/Cook%20and%20Collar%20County%20View.pdf are 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 2 of 35 PageID #:2498
 
of the Congressional Plan, Latino voters are packed into a single congressional district 
racially  gerrymandered  to  capture  an  unnecessarily  excessive  supermajority  of  Latino 
voters, so that the votes of Latinos inside and outside that district are unlawfully diluted. 
Similarly,  the  Proposed  Congressional  Planโwhich  the  New  York  Times  has  called 
โ[p]erhaps the most aggressive example of partisan maneuveringโ to arise out of the 2010 
national census2โeffectively reverses the results of the 2010 congressional elections by 
redrawing districts so that the citizens of Illinois that gave Republicans an 11 to 8 
advantage in Illinoisโs congressional delegation only one year ago would see the stateโs 
congressional  delegation  transformed  to  one  with  12  Democrats  and  only  6 
Republicans (with Illinois having lost one seat in national reapportionment). The 
law does not permit such obviously discriminatory gerrymandering. 
 
  ANSWER:  Defendants admit that the General Assembly passed Illinois Public 
Act 97-14 (the โ2011 Congressional mapโ).  Defendants deny the remaining allegations of 
this paragraph.  
2.    By  packing  excessive  numbers  of  Latino  voters  into  the 
proposed  4th  congressional district, the Proposed Congressional Plan violates the 
Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, the Fifteenth Amendment, and 
Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, 42 U.S.C. ยง 1973. It sacrifices the interests of 
Latino voters in favor of preserving and strengthening white majorities in the proposed 
congressional  districts  that  surround  proposed  District  4โproposed  District  3  and 
proposed  District  5.  Packing  Latino  voters  into  proposed  District  4  unnecessarily 
โwastesโ the supermajority of Latino votes in that district, while also diluting the 
influence  of  Latino  voters  in  proposed  Districts  3  and  5.  The  Proposed 
Congressional Plan converts the District 4 that was created in 1991 in order to 
provide representation to Latinos into one that now denies effective representation 
to Latinos. That intentional discrimination against Latino voters is precisely the kind of 
conduct outlawed by Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, the Equal Protection Clause, 
and the Fifteenth Amendment. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
3.  District  4  of  the  Proposed  Congressional  Plan  also  independently 
violates the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment because it is an 
intentional and unjustified racial gerrymander. The tortured โearmuffโ shape of District 
4, coupled with its extremely large Latino population and the judicially established facts 
about the creation of the district after the 1990 census, leave no doubt that race was the 
                                                                                                                                                  
attached to this Amended Complaint as Exhibits A and B.  Images of the current congressional mapโ
taken from the U.S. Geological Surveyโs National Atlas of the United States, available at 
http://nationalatlas.gov/printable/images/pdg/congdist/pagecgd112_il.pdg are attached to this Amended 
Complaint as Exhibits C and D.  A table reflecting demographic information about the racial and ethnic 
composition of the proposed and current congressional districts is attached as Exhibt E.  
2 Jennifer Steinhauer, For Republicans, Redistricting Offers Few Gains, New York Times A12 (June 12, 2011). 
2 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 3 of 35 PageID #:2499
 
predominant factor in drawing the district and that the district therefore is a racial 
gerrymander. And even if there were a compelling state interest in creating such a 
district, proposed District 4 is not narrowly tailored to accomplish that interest. Given the 
current Latino voting age population in Cook County and nearby, the โearmuffโ district 
no longer complies with the Fourteenth Amendment because there are other viable and 
constitutionally permissible alternatives to proposed District 4. The district, therefore, is 
unconstitutional. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
4.  The  Proposed  Congressional  Plan  also  is  a  partisan  gerrymander  that 
violates  the  First  Amendment  and  the  Equal  Protection  Clause  of  the  Fourteenth 
Amendment. The map as a whole and several individual districts in particular represent a 
flexing of Democratic political muscle in Springfield aimed at creating a Democratic 
majority in the Illinois congressional delegation, regardless of the actual preferences of 
the  electorate  demonstrated  only  one  year  ago.  It  dismantles  traditional  areas  of 
Republican influence such as DuPage County, diluting that influence across multiple 
districts, many carefully connected to traditional areas of Democratic strength. At the 
same time, the map packs Republican incumbents into the same districts or squeezes 
Republican incumbents into Democratic-leaning districts with Democratic incumbents. 
 
  ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
5.  The  dismantling  of  Republican  Congresswoman  Judy  Biggertโs 
current  congressional  District  13  in  Southern  DuPage,  Northern  Will,  and 
Southwestern Cook Counties is particularly striking. Under the Proposed Congressional 
Plan,  Republican-leaning  portions  of  current  District  13  are  packed  into  proposed 
Districts 6 and 14. The removal of those voters from current District 13 allows for the 
creation  of  proposed  District  11,  which  is  a  blatantly  gerrymandered,  irregularly 
shaped district drawn with no apparent reason other than to encompass sufficient 
Democratic voters from Democratic strongholds such as Aurora and Joliet to create a 
new  district  with  a  manufactured  Democratic  majority.  Adding  insult  to  injury, 
proposed District 5 sweeps in a curving hook from the Lake Michigan shoreline on the 
north side of Chicago around the Latino enclaves on Chicagoโs west side that are 
packed into proposed District 4 until it just catches Congresswoman Biggertโs suburban 
Hinsdale home at its very tip. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants admit that District 13 under the 2011 Congressional 
map is different than the Congressional District 13 under the 2001 Congressional map.  
Defendants admit that Congresswoman Judy Biggertโs current residence is located in 
Congressional  District  5  under  the  2011  Congressional  map.    Defendants  deny  the 
remaining allegations contained in this paragraph. 
3 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 4 of 35 PageID #:2500
 
6.  In short, as another New York Times article noted, โ[n]o matter their 
repeated attempts to justify the jigsaw puzzle based on census changes, Democrats took a 
razor to their colleaguesโ domain. They activated every switch at their disposal: clout, 
secrecy and spools of electronic data that guided block-by-block precision.โ3 That back-
room precision was used both to disenfranchise Latino voters and to guide an outrageous 
partisan gerrymander. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
7.  Plaintiffs therefore  file this  action  seeking declaratory and injunctive 
relief to prevent the use of the Proposed Congressional Plan in any future elections. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants  admit  that  Plaintiffs  filed  this  action  and  seek 
declaratory and injunctive relief.  Defendants deny the remaining allegations of this 
paragraph. 
8.  This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 1331, 
1343, and 1357. Plaintiffs bring claims arising under the United States Constitution, 42 
U.S.C. ยง 1983, and 42 U.S.C. ยง 1973 for violations of their civil rights and elective 
franchise. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit that this Court has subject matter jurisdiction 
pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยงยง 1331, 1343, and 1357 and that Plaintiffs purport to bring claims 
arising under the United States Constitution, 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, and 42 U.S.C. ยง 1973.  
Defendants deny the remaining allegations of this paragraph. 
9.  Venue is proper pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391(b) because all defendants 
reside in Illinois and because some of the defendants reside in the Northern District of 
Illinois. By Illinois law, Defendant Illinois State Board of Elections is required to maintain 
an office in the City of Chicago. 10 ILCS ยง 5/1A-11. Pursuant to that requirement, the 
Illinois State Board of Elections maintains an office at 100 W. Randolph Street, Suite 14-
100, Chicago, Illinois. Illinois law also requires four board members of the State Board of 
Elections to be residents of Cook County. 10 ILCS ยง 5/1A-2. Defendant board members 
Ernest Gowen, William McGuffage, Judith Rice, and Bryan Schneider reside in Cook 
County. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants  admit that  venue  is proper  pursuant  to  28 U.S.C. ยง 
                                                
3 Kristen McQueary, Incumbents Carve Out a New Congressional Map, New York Times, A17B (June 3, 
2011). 
4 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 5 of 35 PageID #:2501
 
1391(b).  Defendants state that the Illinois State Board of Electionsโ responsibilities and 
duties are governed, in part, by the Illinois Election Code, 10 ILCS ยง 5/1-1, et al., and that 
the provisions of the Illinois Election Code speak for themselves.  Defendants admit that 
Illinois State Board of Elections maintains an office at 100 W. Randolph Street, Suite 14-
100, Chicago, Illinois and that four board members of the State Board of Elections are 
residents of Cook County: Ernest Gowen, William McGuffage, Judith Rice, and Bryan 
Schneider.  Defendants deny any remaining allegations contained in this paragraph. 
10.  Plaintiff COMMITTEE  FOR A  FAIR  AND  BALANCED MAP is  an 
independent not-for-profit organization created by Illinois citizens concerned about the 
Congressional redistricting process in Illinois. The committee is comprised of the 
following members, who reside in the  following  congressional  districts as noted: 
TOM  LONG  (current  District  19,  proposed  District  13),  TOM  EWING  (current 
District 15, proposed District 16), LARRY  NELSON (current District 14, proposed 
District 14), J. DENNIS HASTERT (current District 14, proposed District 14), JAMES D. 
PEARSON  (current  District 14,  proposed  District  14),  LYNN  MARTIN,  MICHAEL 
KEISER (current District 5, proposed District 5), and ALEXANDER D. STUART (current 
District 10, proposed District 10). 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants admits that Plaintiff, Committee for a Fair and Balanced 
Map, is a not-for-profit organization based in Illinois. Defendants lack knowledge or 
information sufficient to form a belief about the truth of the remaining allegations and, 
therefore, deny the remaining allegations contained in this paragraph. 
11.  Plaintiff RALPH RANGEL is Latino, a citizen, and a registered voter 
whose residence is located in proposed District 3 under the Proposed Congressional 
Map. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
12.  Plaintiff LOU SANDOVAL is Latino, a citizen, and a registered voter 
whose residence is located in proposed District 3 under the Proposed Congressional 
Map. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
13.  Plaintiff LUIS SANABRIA is Latino, a citizen, and a registered voter 
5 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 6 of 35 PageID #:2502
 
whose residence is located in proposed District 4 under the Proposed Congressional 
Map. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
14.  Plaintiff MICHELLE CABALLERO is Latina, a citizen, and a registered 
voter whose residence is located in proposed District 5 under the Proposed Congressional 
Map. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
15.  Plaintiff  EDMUND  BREZINSKI  is  a  Republican,  a  citizen,  and  a 
registered voter who resides in current Congressional District 13 and would reside in 
proposed District 11 under the Proposed Congressional Map. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
16.  Plaintiff LAURA WAXWEILER is a Republican, a citizen, and a registered 
voter who resides in current Congressional District 13 and would reside in proposed 
District 3 under the Proposed Congressional Map. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
17.  Plaintiff PETER J. ROSKAM is the United States Congressman for 
current District 6. He is a  member of the Republican Party and would reside in 
proposed District 6 under the Proposed Congressional Plan. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
18.  Plaintiff JOE WALSH is the United States Congressman for current 
District 8. He is a member of the Republican Party and would reside in proposed 
District 14 under the Proposed Congressional Plan. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
19.  Plaintiff ROBERT J. DOLD is the United States Congressman for current 
District 10. He is a member of the Republican Party and would reside in proposed District 
9 under the Proposed Congressional Plan. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
20.  Plaintiff ADAM KINZINGER is the United States Congressman for 
current District 11. He is a member of the Republican Party and would reside in 
proposed District 2 under the Proposed Congressional Plan. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
6 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 7 of 35 PageID #:2503
 
21.  Plaintiff JUDY  BIGGERT  is  the United States Congresswoman  for 
current District 13. She is a member of the Republican Party and would reside in 
proposed District 5 under the Proposed Congressional Plan.   
 
ANSWER:  Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
22.  Plaintiff RANDY HULTGREN is the United States Congressman for 
current District 14. He is  a  member of the Republican  Party  and  would reside in 
proposed District 14 under the Proposed Congressional Plan.   
 
ANSWER:  Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
23.  Plaintiff DONALD MANZULLO is the United States Congressman for 
current District 16.  He  is  a member of the Republican  Party  and  would reside in 
proposed District 16 under the Proposed Congressional Plan.   
 
ANSWER:  Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
24.  Plaintiff BOBBY SCHILLING is the United States Congressman for 
current District 17. He is a member of the Republican Party and would reside in 
proposed District 17 under the Proposed Congressional Plan.   
 
ANSWER:  Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
25.  Plaintiff AARON SCHOCK is the United States Congressman for current 
District 18. He is a member of the Republican Party and would reside in proposed District 
18 under the Proposed Congressional Plan. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph.  
26.  Plaintiff JOHN M. SHIMKUS is the United States Congressman for 
current District 19. He is a member of the Republican Party and would reside in 
proposed District 15 under the Proposed Congressional Plan. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
27.  Defendant  ILLINOIS  STATE  BOARD  OF  ELECTIONS  is  the  state 
agency required to โ[s]upervise the administration of the registration and election laws 
throughout the State.โ 10 ILCS ยง 5/1A-8(12); Ill Const. 1970, art. III ยง 5. Among other 
duties, the Board must furnish โa manual of uniform instructions ... which shall be used 
by election authorities throughout the state, 10 ILCS ยง 5/1A-8(3), prescribe โuniform 
forms, notices, and other suppliesโ to be used โin the conduct of elections and registrations,โ 
10 ILCS ยง 5/1A-8(4), and โ[r]eview and inspect procedures and records relating to conduct 
of elections and registration ... and to report violations of election lawsโ to appropriate 
authorities. 10 ILCS ยง 5/1A-8(7).  The Board has  eight members, who are named  as 
defendants below (collectively the โIndividual Board Member Defendantsโ). 
7 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 8 of 35 PageID #:2504
 
 
   ANSWER:  Defendants  state  that  the  Illinois  State  Board  of  Elections 
responsibilities and duties are governed, in part, by the Illinois Election Code, 10 ILCS ยง 
5/1-1, et al., and that the provisions of the Illinois Election Code speak for themselves.  
Defendants deny any remaining allegations contained in this paragraph.   
28.  Defendant  WILLIAM  McGUFFAGE  is  the  Chairman  of  the  Illinois 
State Board of Elections. He is sued in his official capacity. 
 
 ANSWER:  Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
29.  Defendant JESSE R. SMART is the Vice Chairman of the Illinois State 
Board of Elections. He is sued in his official capacity. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
30.  Defendant HAROLD D. BYERS is a member of the Illinois State Board 
of Elections. He is sued in his official capacity. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
31.  Defendant BETTY J. COFFRIN is a member of the Illinois State Board 
of Elections. She is sued in her official capacity. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
32.  Defendant ERNEST L. GOWEN is a member of the Illinois State Board 
of Elections. He is sued in his official capacity. 
 
ANSWER: Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
33.  Defendant JUDITH C. RICE is a member of the Illinois State Board of 
Elections. She is sued in her official capacity. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
34.  Defendant BRYAN A. SCHNEIDER is a member of the Illinois State 
Board of Elections. He is sued in his official capacity. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
35.  Defendant CHARLES W. SCHOLZ is a member of the Illinois State 
Board of Elections. He is sued in his official capacity. 
8 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 9 of 35 PageID #:2505
 
 
  ANSWER:  Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
 
36.  As a result of the decennial national census (hereinafter โthe 2010 Censusโ) 
and congressional reapportionment, the State of Illinois lost one of its existing nineteen 
congressional districts.  Beginning in the  next  Congress, Illinois  will have  eighteen 
members of the United States House of Representatives. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants admit the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
37.  The Illinois General Assembly and the Governor of Illinois are charged 
with the duty to enact a plan for dividing the state into congressional districts. In the 
2010 elections, despite gains by Republicans in both chambers of the Illinois General 
Assembly,  Democrats  retained  majority  control  of  both  the  Illinois  House  of 
Representatives  and  the  Illinois  Senate.  Additionally,  the  Democratic  gubernatorial 
candidate won a very close election. As a result, the Democratic Party enjoys unified 
partisan control of state government.  
 
ANSWER:  Defendants  admit  that  the  Illinois  State  Constitution  gives  the 
General Assembly and the Governor the responsibility for redrawing the Congressional and 
legislative political boundaries after the decennial census and reapportionment.  Defendants 
admit that a Democratic governor was elected in the 2010 election.  Defendants admit 
that the current Illinois House and Senate consist of more Democratic members than 
Republican members, but deny the remaining allegations in this paragraph. 
38.  The Proposed Congressional Plan was drawn through backroom channels 
by Illinoisโs Democratic state legislative leaders, Illinoisโs Democratic members of 
the U.S. Congress, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (โDCCCโ) 
and its agents. With respect to areas represented by Republicans, their (privately) stated 
intent  was  to  get  โmore  Democratic  pick-upsโ  and  to  โmaximize  Democratic 
performance.โ  In  other  parts  of  the  State,  however,  the  mapmakers  monitored  and 
massaged the Latino voting age population in crucial districts they wanted to keep safe 
for white incumbents in the face of surging Latino populations. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
39.  While the backroom mapmaking proceeded out of public view, members of 
the Illinois House of Representatives and the Illinois Senate held a series of hearings at 
locations around the state between March 28, 2011 and May 2, 2011 pursuant to 10 ILCS 
125/10-5. The hearings were conducted by the Illinois Senate Redistricting Committee 
and  the  Illinois  House  Redistricting  Committee.    The  chairpersons  of  those 
9 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 10 of 35 PageID #:2506
 
committeesโState  Senator Kwame Raoul, a Democrat,  and  House  Majority Leader 
Barbara Flynn Currie, also a Democratโcontrolled the conduct of the hearings.4 Members 
of the public were permitted to comment, in theory, on the redistricting process and their 
respective  communities  of  interest.  However,  pursuant  to  a  rule  established  by  the 
Democratic chairpersons of the committees, members of the public were not permitted to 
ask questions of the members of the Redistricting Committees. As stated by Senator Raoul 
at the first hearing after the state legislative map was released, โWeโre taking input today. 
Weโre not fielding questions.โ5 In addition, during the purported public hearings, 
the Democratic-controlled committee never presented any draft or proposed congressional 
maps or redistricting plan for the public to consider. 
 
  ANSWER:  Defendants admit that, pursuant to 10 ILCS ยง 125/10-5, members 
of the Illinois Senate Redistricting Committee and House Redistricting Committees 
held public hearings regarding the redistricting process throughout Illinois between 
March 28, 2011 and May 2, 2011.  Defendants admit that Democratic State Senator 
Kwame  Raoul  was the  chairperson of the Illinois  Senate  Redistricting  Committee.  
Defendants admit that Democratic House Majority Leader Barbara Flynn Currie was the 
chairperson  of  the  Illinois  House  Redistricting  Committee.    Defendants  admit  that 
members  of  the  public  commented  at  hearings  regarding  the  redistricting  process.  
Defendants admit that the transcripts of the hearings reflect the remarks of the Members of 
the Senate and House and the public and that these transcripts speak for themselves.  
Defendants deny the remaining allegations of this paragraph.  Answering further, both the 
House and Senate Redistricting Committees consisted of Republican members of the House 
and Senate, including but not limited to: Rep. Mike Fortner; Rep. Jim Durkin; Rep. Chapin 
Rose; Rep. Timothy Schmitz; Rep. Jill Tracy; Sen. Dale A. Righter; Sen. Shane Cultra; Sen. 
Kirk W. Dillard; Sen. Dan Duffy; Sen. David S. Luechtefeld; and Sen. Mat Murphy.  
4  0.        With respect to the congressional reapportionment plan, numerous commenters 
urged that โitโs crucial that input be heard after draft maps are released and when we can 
                                                
4 See http://www.ilsenateredistricting.com. 
5 Senator Kwame Raoul, Illinois State Senate Hearing (May 21, 2011), at 69. 
10 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 11 of 35 PageID #:2507
 
give specific feedback about how the lines will affect our communities.โ6 Moreover, 
numerous citizen commenters, as well as Republican legislators, implored the Democratic 
leadership of the committees to release proposed maps at least one or two weeks before 
any vote would be taken, to allow for public comment.7 Chairman Raoul pledged to do 
precisely that, stating โ[i]tโs my intention to, you know, as soon as thereโs a rendering of a 
map, to post that up so people can see that and so we can have hearings afterwards and 
so people can be informed.โ8 Unfortunately, as set forth below, the Senator reneged on 
that pledge. 
 
  ANSWER:  Defendants lack sufficient knowledge or information to form a belief 
as  to  what  โnumerous  commentersโ  requested  of  the  Democratic  leadership  of  the 
redistricting committees, and, therefore, deny this allegation. Further answering, both the 
Senate Redistricting Committee and the House Redistricting Committee had multiple 
hearings throughout the state of Illinois where members of the public and interest groups 
participated and offered opinions as to what the General Assembly should consider when 
drafting the legislative and Congressional maps.  Defendants admit that the transcripts of 
the hearings reflect the remarks of the Members of the Senate and House and the public 
and  that  these  transcripts  speak  for  themselves.    Defendants  deny  the  remaining 
allegations contained in this paragraph. 
41.  On May 18, 2011, the Democratic leadership of the Redistricting Committees 
released a proposed state legislative map on the Illinois Senate Redistricting Committee 
website. The congressional map was not released at that time. Redistricting Committees 
in the Illinois Senate and the Illinois House of Representatives held three hearingsโon 
May 21, 22, and 24, 2011โon the proposed state map. During those meetings, several 
public commenters pleaded for the immediate release of the congressional map, to no 
                                                
6http://www.ilga.gov/senate/Committees/Redistricting/Final%20Approved%20Transcript%20for%20Senate%2
0Redistricting%20Hearing%203.28.11.pdf, at 37. See also id. at 43 (โSo that points to the need for meaningful 
considering of our input, not just now but also after draft maps are made available.โ). See also 
http://www.ilhousedems.com/redistricting/hearings/ Champaign-April-16/Champaign041611.pdf, at 9 (โBut if 
we donโt come back here with a map prior to it being voted on so that you all citizens have a comment period on 
it, then this really would be for naught.โ); id. at 86 (โThe public should be allowed to see and comment on any 
new map that is drawn by the General Assembly at least two weeks before they are voted on by the House and 
the Senate in this session of the General Assembly.โ); id. at 96 (โBut at least two weeks before the vote, the map 
should be disclosed to the public.โ). 
7http://www.ilga.gov/senate/Committees/Redistricting/Final%20Approved%20Transcript 
8 Id. at 165. 
11 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 12 of 35 PageID #:2508
 
avail.9   
ANSWER:  Defendants admit that, on May 18, 2011, a draft state legislative map 
was posted on the Illinois Senate Redistricting Web site and that the Illinois Senate and 
House of Representatives Redistricting Committees held hearings regarding that draft 
map on May 21, 22, and 24, 2011.  Defendants lack sufficient knowledge or information 
to form a belief as for what several commenters publicly pleaded during the May 21, 22 
and 24, 2011 redistricting hearings and, therefore, deny this allegation.  Defendants admit 
that the transcripts of the hearings reflect the remarks of the Members of the Senate and 
House and the public and that these transcripts speak for themselves.  Defendants deny the 
remaining allegations of this paragraph. 
42.  At approximately 4:00 a.m., in the early morning hours of Friday, May 27,

ANSWER:  Defendants lack knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief 
about the truth of the allegations contained in this paragraph and, therefore, deny the 
allegations contained in this paragraph. 
88.  The  Proposed  Congressional  Plan  places  incumbent  Republican 
Congressmen Joe Walsh and Randy Hultgren in proposed District 14, forcing them to run 
against each other in the Republican primary or move. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants admit that Congressmen Joe Walshโs current residence 
is  located  in  District  14  in  the  2011  Congressional  map.  Defendants  admit  that 
Congressman Randy Hultgrenโs current residence is located in District 14 in the 2011 
Congressional map.  Defendants lack knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief 
about the truth of the remaining allegations and, therefore, deny the remaining allegations 
contained in this paragraph. 
89.  The Proposed Congressional Plan does not place a single Democratic 
incumbent in the same Congressional district as another Democratic incumbent. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants state that the current residences of Democratic incumbent 
U.S. Representatives are each in separate districts under the 2011 Congressional map.  
Defendants deny the remaining allegations contained in this paragraph.  
90.  The  Proposed  Congressional  Plan  places  incumbent  Republican 
Congressman Adam Kinzinger and incumbent Democratic Congressman Jesse Jackson, 
Jr. in proposed District 2. Proposed District 2 is significantly weighted in favor of a 
Democratic candidate.  Proposed  District 2  contains 78% of Congressman Jacksonโs 
current district. Also, in the 2010 Illinois gubernatorial election, proposed District 2 
voted 70.76% in favor of the Democratic candidate and only 20.50% in favor of the 
Republican candidate. In the 2008 and 2004 Presidential elections, it voted 80.64% 
and 73.56% in favor of the Democratic candidate and only 17.57% and 24.17% in favor 
of the Republican candidate. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants state that the current residences of Congressman Adam 
25 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 26 of 35 PageID #:2522
 
Kinzinger and Congressman Jesse Jackson Jr. are located in District 2 under the 2011 
Congressional map. Defendants lack knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief 
about the truth of the remaining allegations and, therefore, deny the remaining allegations 
contained in this paragraph. 
91.  As  already  noted,  the  Proposed  Congressional  Plan  places  incumbent 
Republican Congresswoman Judy Biggert and incumbent Democratic Congressman 
Mike Quigley in proposed District 5. Proposed District 5 is significantly weighted in 
favor of a Democratic candidate. Proposed District 5 contains 72% of Congressman 
Quigleyโs current district. Also, in the 2010 Illinois gubernatorial election, it voted 
54.18%  in  favor  of  the  Democratic  candidate  and  only  36.17%  in  favor  of  the 
Republican candidate. In the 2008 and 2004 Presidential elections, it voted 68.62% 
and 62.59% in favor of the Democratic Candidate and only 28.89% and 35.22% in favor 
of the Republican candidate. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants state that the current residences of Congresswoman Judy 
Biggert  and  Congressman  Mike  Quigley  are  located  in  District  5  under  the  2011 
Congressional map.  Defendants lack knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief 
about the truth of the remaining allegations and, therefore, deny the remaining allegations 
contained in this paragraph. 
92.  The  Proposed  Congressional  Plan  places  incumbent  Republican 
Congressman Bob Dold and incumbent Democratic Congresswoman Jan Schakowsky in 
proposed  District  9.  Proposed  District  9  is  significantly  weighted  in  favor  of  a 
Democratic  candidate.  Proposed  District  9  contains  77%  of  Congresswoman 
Schakowskyโs current district. Also, in the 2010 Illinois gubernatorial election, it voted 
55.30%  in  favor  of  the  Democratic  candidate  and  only  36.68%  in  favor  of  the 
Republican candidate. In the 2008 and 2004 Presidential elections, it voted 67.74% and 
62.63% in favor of the Democratic Candidate and only 30.17% and 35.03% in favor of the 
Republican candidate. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants state that the current residences of Congresswoman Jan 
Schakowsky  and  Congressman  Bob  Dold  are  located  in  District  9  under  the  2011 
Congressional map.   Defendants lack knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief 
about the truth of the remaining allegations and, therefore, deny the remaining allegations 
26 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 27 of 35 PageID #:2523
 
contained in this paragraph. 
93.  The Proposed Congressional Plan also favors Democratic incumbents in 
terms of overlap of population between current and proposed congressional districts. 
The  Proposed  Congressional  Plan  places  Republican  incumbents  in  districts  whose 
population overlaps with an average of 34.20% of their current districts. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants lack knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief 
about the truth of the allegations contained in this paragraph and, therefore, deny the 
allegations contained in this paragraph. 
94.  By  contrast,  the  Proposed  Congressional  Plan  places  Democratic 
incumbents in districts whose population overlaps with an average of 77.52% of their 
current districts. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants lack knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief 
about the truth of the allegations and, therefore, deny the allegations contained in this 
paragraph. 
95.  The population overlaps for Democratic incumbents range from a high of 
100.0% (proposed District 12) to a low of 76.3% (proposed District 3), with an average 
of 87.8%  across  all  Democratic  incumbents.  The  highest  Republican  incumbentโs 
population overlap is only 67.9% (proposed District 18), while the lowest is a mere 
1.3% (proposed District 5), with an average of 34.4% across all Republican incumbents. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants lack knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief 
about the truth of the allegations and, therefore, deny the allegations contained in this 
paragraph. 
96.  The  Proposed  Congressional  Plan  also  unnecessarily  splits  a  significant 
number of prominent and populous communities, including Bloomington, Champaign, 
DeKalb, Peoria, Rockford, and Urbana, into multiple congressional districts, reducing 
the ability of these communities to select representatives of their choice. It also divides 
significant  Chicago  suburbs  (with  populations  greater  than  25,000  people), 
including Algonquin, Carol Stream, Carpentersville, Cicero, Crystal Lake, Glen 
Ellyn, Glendale Heights, Glenview, Gurnee, Hanover Park, Lake in the Hills, Melrose 
Park, Mundelein, Oswego, Streamwood, Waukegan, Wheaton, and Woodridge, as well as 
Chicagoโs Chinatown neighborhood. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph.  
27 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 28 of 35 PageID #:2524
 
97.  The  Proposed  Congressional  Plan  is  less  compact  than  the  present 
congressional map.   
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
98.  The  present  congressional  map  has  a  Circularity  Ratio  of  0.19.  The 
Proposed Congressional Plan has a Circularity Ratio of 0.16. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph.     
99.  The present congressional map has a ratio of the circumference of an 
equal  area  circle  divided  by  the  perimeter  of  the  proposed  districts  of  0.45.  The 
Proposed Congressional Plan has a ratio of 0.41. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants lack knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief 
about the truth of the allegations and, therefore, deny the allegations contained in this 
paragraph. 
100.  The present congressional map has a Schwartzberg Test ratio of 0.64. 
The Proposed Congressional Plan has a ratio of 0.61. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants lack knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief 
about the truth of the allegations and, therefore, deny the allegations contained in this 
paragraph. 
101.  By  diluting  the  votes  of  Republican  votersโincluding  plaintiffs 
Committee for a Fair and Balanced Map, Peter J. Roskam, Joe Walsh, Robert J. Dold, 
Adam Kinzinger, Judy Biggert, Randy Hultgren, Donald Manzullo, Bobby Schilling, 
Aaron Schock, John M. Shimkus, Laura Waxweiler, and Edmund Brezinski (collectively, 
the โPartisan Gerrymander Plaintiffsโ)โ the partisan gerrymander embodied in the 
Proposed Congressional Plan intentionally discriminates against Republican voters 
and penalizes Republican voters based on their voting history and other expressions of 
political views. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
102.  The Illinois State Board of Elections has โgeneral supervision over 
the administration of the registration and election laws throughout the State,โ Ill. Const. 
1970, art. III ยง 5; 10 ILCS ยง 5/1A-1, and must โ[s]upervise the administration of the 
registration and election laws throughout the State.โ 10 ILCS ยง 5/1A-8(12). 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants  state  that  the  Illinois  State  Board  of  Electionsโ 
28 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 29 of 35 PageID #:2525
 
responsibilities and duties are governed, in part, by the Illinois Election Code, 10 ILCS ยง 
5/1-1, et al., and that the provisions of the Illinois Election Code speak for themselves.   
103.  In  accordance  with  that  mandate,  the  State  Board  of  Elections  is 
required to, among other  things, โ[d]isseminate  information to  and  consult  with 
election authorities concerning the conduct of elections and registrationโ 10 ILCS ยง 5/1A-
8(2), furnish โa manual of uniform instructions ... which shall be used by election 
authoritiesโ throughout the state, 10 ILCS ยง 5/1A-8(3), prescribe โuniform forms, 
notices, and other suppliesโ to be used โin the conduct of elections and registrations,โ 
10 ILCS ยง 5/1A-8(4), โ[r]eview and inspect procedures and records relating to conduct 
of elections and registration ... and to report violations of election lawsโ to appropriate 
authorities. 10 ILCS ยง 5/1A-8(7). 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants  state  that  the  Illinois  State  Board  of  Electionsโ 
responsibilities and duties are governed, in part, by the Illinois Election Code, 10 ILCS ยง 
5/1-1, et al., and that the provisions of the Illinois Election Code speak for themselves.   
104.  The first day to circulate petitions for party nominations for United 
States Congress for the 2012 Illinois primary election is ninety days before the last day to 
file petitions, i.e., September 6, 2011. 10 ILCS ยง 5/7-10. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants state that the Illinois Election Code, 10 ILCS ยง 5/1-1, et 
al., and the provisions therein speak for themselves.  Defendants further state that petitions 
for party nominations for United States Congress for the 2012 Illinois primary election 
may not be circulated prior to September 6, 2011 pursuant to 10 ILCS ยงยง 5/7-12, 7-10.   
105.  The first day to file petitions for party nominations for United States 
Congress for the 2012 Illinois primary election is November 28, 2011. 10 ILCS ยง 5/7-12, 
as recently amended by Public Act 96-1008. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants state that the Illinois Election Code, 10 ILCS ยง 5/1-1, et 
al., and the provisions therein speak for themselves.  Defendants further state that the first 
day to file petitions for party nominations for United States Congress for the 2012 Illinois 
primary election is November 28, 2011 pursuant to 10 ILCS ยงยง 5/7-12, 7-10.   
106.  The last day to file petitions  for party nominations for United States 
Congress for the 2012 Illinois primary election is December 5, 2011. Id. 
29 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 30 of 35 PageID #:2526
 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants state that the Illinois Election Code, 10 ILCS ยง 5/1-1, et 
al., and the provisions therein speak for themselves.  Defendants further state that the last 
day to file petitions for party nominations for United States Congress for the 2012 Illinois 
primary election is December 5, 2011 pursuant to 10 ILCS ยงยง 5/7-12, 7-10.   
107.  The 2012 Illinois primary election for United States Congress is March 
20, 2012. 10 ILCS ยง 5/2A-1.1(a), as recently amended by Public Act 96-866. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants state that the next General Primary Election will occur 
on March 20, 2012.   
CAUSES OF ACTION 
COUNT I 
(Violation of 42 U.S.C. ยง 1973 against All Defendants 
brought by the Racial Dilution Plaintiffs) 
 
108.  Plaintiffs reallege the facts set forth in paragraphs 1 through 107, above. 
ANSWER:  Defendants reallege their answers to paragraphs 1 through 107 
above as the answer to this paragraph. 
109.  Count  I  is  brought  by the  Racial  Dilution  Plaintiffs  against  Defendant 
Illinois State Board of Elections as well as the Individual Board Member Defendants in their 
official capacities. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants  admit  that  Plaintiffs  bring  this  Count  against  the 
Defendant,  Illinois  State  Board  of  Elections,  as  well  as the  Individual  Board  Member 
Defendants in their official capacities, but deny that there is any validity to this Count. 
110.  The Proposed Congressional Plan intentionally discriminates against Latino 
voters on the basis of their race. The Plan intentionally dilutes the votes of Latino voters by 
packing an excessive super-majority of Latino voters into proposed District 4 and 
by simultaneously reducing the growing percentage of Latino voters in proposed Districts 3 
and 5. Many Latino voters in proposed District 4 will see their votes wasted because 
the Plan intentionally makes those votes unnecessary to elect a candidate of their choice. 
At the same time, Latino voters in proposed Districts 3 and 5 will be prevented by their 
intentionally  diminished  numbers  from  having  any  significant  influence  in  choosing 
primary and general election candidates of their choice. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
30 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 31 of 35 PageID #:2527
 
111.  As a result, the Proposed Congressional Plan denies or abridges the right of 
the Racial Dilution Plaintiffs to vote, on account of their race or color, and affords the 
Racial  Dilution  Plaintiffs  less  opportunity  than  other  members  of  the  electorate  to 
participate in the political process and to elect representatives of their choice. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
112.  Accordingly, the Proposed Congressional Plan violates Section 2 of the 
Voting Rights Act, 42 U.S.C. ยง 1973. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
COUNT II 
(Violation of the Equal Protection Clause, actionable under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, against the 
Individual Board Member Defendants brought by the Racial Dilution Plaintiffs) 
 
113.  Plaintiffs reallege the facts set forth in paragraphs 1 through 107, above. 
ANSWER:  Defendants reallege their answers to paragraphs 1 through 107 
above as the answer to this paragraph.  
114.  Count II is brought by the Racial Dilution Plaintiffs against the Individual 
Board Member Defendants in their official capacities. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants  admit  that  Plaintiffs  bring  this  Count  against  the 
Individual Board Member Defendants in their official capacities, but deny that there is any 
validity to this Count. 
115.  The  Proposed  Congressional  Plan  intentionally  discriminates  against 
Latino voters on the basis of their race. The Plan intentionally dilutes the votes of Latino 
voters by packing an excessive super-majority of Latino voters into proposed District 
4 and  by simultaneously reducing the growing percentage of Latino voters in proposed 
Districts 3 and 5. Many Latino voters in proposed District 4 will see their votes wasted 
because the Plan intentionally makes those votes unnecessary to elect a candidate of their 
choice.  At the same time, Latino voters in proposed Districts 3 and 5 will be prevented 
by  their  intentionally  diminished  numbers  from  having  any  significant  influence  in 
choosing primary and general election candidates of their choice. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
116.  As a result, the Proposed Congressional Plan intentionally treats the Racial 
Dilution Plaintiffs differently and worse than it treats similarly situated voters who are 
not Latino. And the Plan does so because the Racial Dilution Plaintiffs are Latino. 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
31 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 32 of 35 PageID #:2528
 
 
117.  Accordingly, the Proposed Congressional Plan violates the Equal Protection 
Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, made actionable in 
this suit by 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983. 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
 
COUNT III 
(Violation of the Fifteenth Amendment, actionable under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, against the 
Individual Board Member Defendants brought by the Racial Dilution Plaintiffs) 
 
118.  Plaintiffs reallege the facts set forth in paragraphs 1 through 107, above. 
ANSWER:  Defendants reallege their answers to paragraphs 1 through 107 
above as the answer to this paragraph. 
119.  Count III is brought by the Racial Dilution Plaintiffs against the Individual 
Board Member Defendants in their official capacities. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants  admit  that  Plaintiffs  bring  this  Count  against  the 
Individual Board Member Defendants in their official capacities, but deny that there is any 
validity to this Count. 
120.  The  Proposed  Congressional  Plan  intentionally  discriminates  against 
Latino voters on the basis of their race. The Plan intentionally dilutes the votes of Latino 
voters by packing an excessive super-majority of Latino voters into proposed District 
4 and  by simultaneously reducing the growing percentage of Latino voters in proposed 
Districts 3 and 5. Many Latino voters in proposed District 4 will see their votes wasted 
because the Plan intentionally makes those votes unnecessary to elect a candidate of their 
choice. At the same time, Latino voters in proposed Districts 3 and 5 will be prevented 
by  their  intentionally  diminished  numbers  from  having  any  significant  influence  in 
choosing primary and general election candidates of their choice.   
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
121.  As a result, the Proposed Congressional Plan denies or abridges the right of 
the Racial Dilution Plaintiffs to vote, on account of their race or color. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
122.  Accordingly, the Proposed Congressional Plan violates the Fifteenth 
Amendment to the United States Constitution, made actionable in this suit by 42 U.S.C. ยง 
1983. 
 
32 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 33 of 35 PageID #:2529
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
COUNT IV 
(Violation of the Equal Protection Clause, actionable under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, against the 
Individual Board Member Defendants brought by the Racial Gerrymander Plaintiff) 
 
123.  Plaintiffs reallege the facts set forth in paragraphs 1 through 107, above. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants reallege their answers to paragraphs 1 through 107 
above as the answer to this paragraph. 
124.  Count IV is brought by the Racial Gerrymander Plaintiff against the 
Individual Board Member Defendants in their official capacities. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants  admit  that  Plaintiffs  bring  this  Count  against  the 
Individual Board Member Defendants in their official capacities, but deny that there is any 
validity to this Count. 
125.  The Proposed Congressional Plan intentionally made raceโnamely, Latino 
ethnicityโthe predominant factor in the creation of proposed District 4. That proposed District 
disregards traditional districting principles such as compactness, contiguity, and respect for 
political subdivisions. Instead, it manufactures a Latino voting age supermajority of 65.92% 
by packing Latino residents into an earmuff-shaped district so bizarre on its face that race is the 
only explanation for the shape and demographic composition of the District. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
126.  Proposed District 4 is not narrowly tailored to serve an interest in complying 
with the Voting  Rights Act  because  it includes far more  Latino voters than  would  be 
necessary to comply with that law and a Latino majority district can be drawn without racial 
gerrymandering. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
127.  As a result, proposed District 4 impermissibly classifies the Racial Gerrymander 
Plaintiff by his race. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
128.  Accordingly, District 4 of the Proposed Congressional Plan violates the Equal 
Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, made 
actionable in this suit by 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983. 
 
ANSWER:  Defendants deny the allegations contained in this paragraph. 
33 
 

Case: 1:11-cv-05065 Document #: 124 Filed: 11/11/11 Page 34 of 35 PageID #:2530
 
COUNT V 
(Violation of the First Amendment, actionable under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, against the 
Individual Board Member Defendants brought by the Partisan Gerrymander Plaintiffs) 
 
Defendants have moved to dismiss Count V of the Amended Complaint.  
Accordingly, no answer is required. 
COUNT VI 
(Violation of the Equal Protection Clause, actionable under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, against 
the Individual Board Member Defendants brought by the Partisan Gerrymander 
Plaintiffs) 
 
Defendants have moved to dismiss Count VI of the Amended Complaint.  
Accordingly, no answer is required.
